name: President. –
text: The next item is the report by Ernest Urtasun, on behalf of the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality, on Gender Equality in EU’s foreign and security policy (2019/2167(INI)) (A9-0145/2020). I would like to inform Members that for all debates of this part-session, there will be no catch-the-eye procedure and that no blue cards and points of order will be accepted. Furthermore, possible remote interventions from Parliament’s Liaison Offices in the Member States are foreseen.

name: Ernest Urtasun
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I’m very pleased to be presenting today, with my dear colleague Hannah Neumann, the first ever European Parliament report outlining all the political, institutional and funding aspects needed for the achievement of gender equality in EU foreign and security policy.  In light of the current global challenges, like the climate emergency and growing trends towards authoritarianism, where women and girls are the most impacted, the need for a gender-based EU foreign and security policy becomes more urgent than ever. Following the example of a number of countries, we want the EU and its institutions to follow a similar path. The EU has taken already some important steps in this direction, like the Gender Action Plans I and II or the women, peace and security agenda. However their implementation still displays a number of shortcomings.  In the report we present several recommendations to be considered in the upcoming new Gender Action Plan 2021-25 that will be published shortly. Starting with political representation and participation in decision-making processes, we ask for a gender quota of 50% at all levels of the Commission and EEAS management by 2024, including heads of delegation and heads of CSDP missions. Mandatory training courses on gender equality, with special attention to middle and upper managers of the EEAS and heads of CSDP missions and operations, should also be introduced.  More resources need to be assigned to the EEAS Principal Advisor on Gender to continue and reinforce her work. Therefore, we call on the High Representative to continue his efforts in this area by appointing a full-time gender adviser in each EEAS directorate and to establish gender focal points in all EU delegations. We also need to increase the efficient use of existing and future EU resources through gender responsive budgeting.  As we negotiate at the moment the proposed neighbourhood development and international cooperation instrument we should make gender mainstreaming and targeted actions clear objectives under that regulation and ensure that partners can count on sufficient political and financial support to implement it.  At the same time the EU needs to dedicate efforts to monitor the backlash against gender equality and LGBTIQ+ rights in the world, promote the human rights of women and protect women human rights defenders. In particular, sexual and reproductive health and rights are being threatened inside the EU but also outside; particularly, in crisis zones, women and girls are exposed to sexual violence, sexually transmitted diseases, sexual exploitation and rape as a weapon of war. Therefore, we call on the EU and its Member States to take steps to protect women and their sexual rights in their humanitarian aid response, as well as access to justice. The year 2020 marks the anniversary of several key events: the 20th anniversary of the UN Security Council resolution 1325 on Women, Peace and Security, the 14th anniversary of the UN Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women, and the 25th anniversary of the Beijing Declaration on women’s rights. The EU’s role has been crucial in advancing on all these milestones, but it needs to stand out now in its commitment to make gender equality a priority in its foreign and security policy. I hope this report will contribute to achieving this goal and I would like to thank all the colleagues, also some of them present here in the room, for their support and their cooperation in achieving that draft report.

name: Hannah Neumann
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. – Mr President, when Operation Sophia, the one that was actually still allowed to do search and rescue in the Mediterranean, was launched in 2015, there were long discussions about the operation plans because it was different, a new mission. Most of the discussion was about what kind of weapons this mission would need to overpower people on the boats and what kind of specific training to do that. At some point, it was a woman who asked about sanitary napkins and diapers because there would be women and small children on the boats and they would be on the ships with us for quite some days. In the end, the sanitary napkins and the diapers were used much more than the weapons. This example just shows how more diversity leads to better decisions and, yes, sometimes it is that stereotypical. The same is true when we speak about peace negotiations because peace deals last longer if women are involved, because societies are more peaceful if they are gender equal, but still to this day negotiation tables and the whole field of peace and security is a male domain. I can’t even remember how many rooms I walked into in the last 15 years where I was the only woman, either being ignored or stared at curiously.  That’s why we dedicated large parts of this report to our own EU institutions and our own EU budget because there we actually have 100% of the power to change it and no excuses. That’s why we ask for 50% of women in CSDP missions in our own services. That’s why we want a specific part of the foreign budget to go into projects that empower women and girls to claim their spot because they know how it works. There was an amazing spirit during our negotiations in the committee because I think we all agree that we want an EU foreign policy that is for everybody. But now it’s time to change the reality out there and to really speed things up on women, peace and security. That’s why, Ms Urpilainen, but also Mr Borrell and the whole Commission, you had better come up with an ambitious gender action plan towards the end of this year.

name: Jutta Urpilainen
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the debate on the participation and role of women in foreign and security policy is relevant at any moment and one I’m very attached to. I fully agree with your report on the necessity to accelerate our ongoing work on gender equality and women’s rights. First, the COVID-19 context – now more than ever – requires a response at the global scale which fully integrates a gender perspective in all our analyses and responses to the pandemic and in the recovery phase. The EU has been frontloading actions to support women and girls in the crisis, notably through the EU-UN Spotlight Initiative. Under this initiative, we were able to adopt priority actions on the elimination of all forms of gender-based violence as urgent needs. We prioritised helplines and shelters for victims of domestic violence and frontline support for women’s grass roots organisations. We must transform this into an opportunity to review and accelerate our engagement to promote gender equality within the EU and around the world. Second, I welcome your call for robust implementation of the EU Action Plan on Women, Peace and Security. The EU is at the forefront of the implementation of the UN Security Council Resolution 1325. Allow me to highlight the importance of holding this discussion today a few days before the 20th anniversary of the adoption of this milestone transformative document. In this context, I fully – I fully – share your view on the importance of the gender advisers and we have already paved new ground through the establishment of posts for gender advisers and the creation of the gender focal points networks in military and civilian operations and missions of our common security and defence policy. Finally, I am very glad to confirm that I will present with the High Representative in November a new EU Gender Action Plan (GAP) III. It will enable us to reaffirm gender equality and women’s and girls’ empowerment as a core priority of all EU External Action. GAP III takes the thread from the recent EU Gender Equality Strategy and is the first such EU policy framework on gender equality externally. It draws from the lessons learned from the COVID-19 pandemic, with a focus on building back better from the crisis by addressing structural inequalities. It will integrate the Women, Peace and Security Agenda, as called for in your report. It will also expand action in key areas of engagement, addressing new challenges and opportunities in line with the Commission’s political priorities, such as ensuring a fair and inclusive green transition and managing the digital transformation. Last, but not least, it will very much – very much – draw on your recommendations regarding the need for the EU and its staff to set the example on gender equality and to promote gender-responsive leadership in achieving this. Mr President, the EU must continue to reaffirm that women’s rights are human rights. The ambition is there for a gender-sensitive and responsive geopolitical Commission and I thank this House for its support. I’m looking forward to our discussion. (Applause)

name: Frances Fitzgerald
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, women’s rights are human rights, indeed. It is critical that foreign policy, security and defence, peacebuilding, reconciliation and justice are viewed as domains where women’s contributions are central. These areas can never again be seen solely through a male lens. This report is yet another critical step and must be implemented. Women have always been affected by war and peace, as confidants, as victims and as the hidden advisors behind the men at the table: wives, daughters, sisters, soldiers and simply those experiencing the frontline. Whether we are speaking about the women in Rwanda, whether we are talking about Kurdish women, or indeed the women of Northern Ireland who came together to say ‘enough’, and who contributed hugely to, and guided, the peace process towards the Good Friday Agreement. Foreign policy more and more – increasingly, but not enough – is guided by strong, brave and ambitious women. It is a statement of fact that women need to be involved, as strongly endorsed by the UN 20 years ago next week with the adoption of the Security Council resolution. I am very proud that Ireland’s recent campaign for membership of the Security Council placed the advancement of the ideals in the resolution on women, peace and security at its core, recognising that building lasting peace is not possible without building a more equal and inclusive society. That’s what this report is about. Let’s make sure that gender equality applies in these arenas with a critical mass of women. Let us take advantage of women’s unique perspective and ensure the barriers that continue to keep women excluded from political decision-making fora are urgently removed. Let’s act together here in the EU institutions to ensure that.

name: Alessandra Moretti
text: Mr President, Madam Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we often say that the gender issue must go through all European policies, the Commission and its President have declared it one of the most important challenges, and we parliamentarians through the gender mainstreaming network have said that they are ready to go down this road and ask for the resources necessary to achieve this objective. By voting for this report, we can finally take a concrete step towards a policy that includes needs, but above all the resources that women can put in place. Women are an essential value for the growth and development of our society. Our action must be an instrument for guaranteeing human rights, including the rights of women and girls, who are the first to be sacrificed. Access to sexual and reproductive health services is a prerequisite for gender equality and therefore for progress and well-being. And climate change is often the cause of the erosion of these rights. Gender stereotypes persist that drive women to migrate at the risk of violence, exploitation and trafficking in human beings. How, then, can we talk about environmental foreign policy, migration, without taking gender equality into account? I would like to thank the rapporteur and all those who have contributed to the drafting of a progressive text, which finally looks to women as agents of change and not as victims, which studies the issue of foreign policy, not just a flat description of the status quo, but which puts people of all kinds, backgrounds and ages at the centre.

name: Samira Rafaela
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, freedom, peace and stability are too valuable to leave in the hands of men alone.  Women make up half of our society. Their participation in foreign and security policy is not only a matter of representation, it is also vital for sustainable peace. Unfortunately, the idea of a gender sensitive and inclusive foreign and security policy is not engrained in our societies.  Worse yet, our very own EU institutions lack in this. I am astonished to learn that we have still not progressed on this. Our gender action plan is not implemented properly. We have a lack of gender responsive budgeting, and no gender sensitive institutional structure to reach these critical goals. How is it possible that men still hold 87% of senior management posts in the European External Action Service? We should be embarrassed, and as the EU we lose credibility as proponents of equal rights for men and women in Europe and abroad.  I have said this before and I will say this again: walk the talk.  That is why we as the EU Parliament call for corrective measures. We want binding political commitments for a target of 50% of women in management positions, including heads of delegation and in our common security and defence policy missions and operations.  Let me remind you, 2020 marks important anniversaries of the Beijing Declaration and the UN Security Council resolution 1325 on women, peace and security. This UN resolution stresses the importance of women’s equal participation in the maintenance and promotion of peace and security around the globe. They know what is necessary for their own security and safety. These vital conditions contribute to an inclusive and sustainable future for all of us. As we look for alliances in the region, and internationally, it is important that our institutions at home reflect our vision for abroad, where we reach out to women who have been left behind. The future will challenge us in new and unpredictable ways and it is important we adapt to this. I urge Member States in the EU to adopt a feminist foreign and security policy, leaving no one behind, as we strive for common peace and security at home and abroad.  Striving for equal representation means sustainable peace and security for everyone.

name: Guido Reil
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Today we are talking about the report on equality between men and women in the context of foreign and security policy. So I think this headline is a scandal, because we are talking about men and women and have forgotten the various things – so that is completely wrong politically! Thank God, when I read the report intensively, I noticed that, of course, the various genders and sexual orientations play a very decisive role. How else should foreign and security policy be managed, it goes without saying? Furthermore, this report emphasises the need for a feminist foreign and security policy. It is also, of course, very important that we have a gender-specific asylum and migration policy.  And, of course, we are once again confronting the ultimate opponent – climate change. We learn that climate change is particularly misogynistic, because it is particularly a problem for women and girls. When I look at the activists of Fridays for Future, I really have to get this impression, there are actually many girls active who usually come from very good homes, who are rich, such as the offspring of the Shipping Family Reemtsma.  But I can't understand that. Why are girls and why are rich girls so affected? And just about climate change? I have met many women in the course of my life, the vast majority of them like to have it warm because women are freezing. Allow me to have this little fun, because I can't bear all the madness. It is all about creating well-paid jobs for women and for diversity. Jobs that the general public have to pay for, and that must finally stop! Stop this ideological madness!

name: Charlie Weimers
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, we used to think that sex should not be an obstacle, nor a factor, in recruitment. Not anymore. This report on gender in foreign policy obsesses over individuals’ sex. It calls for binding quotas for management positions, it references gender mainstreaming, also known as radical feminism, 24 times, and intersectional analysis, a.k.a. Balkanisation, seven times. It calls for increased funding and staff to implement gender ideology, with a full-time gender adviser in each EEAS Directorate. I suppose the title ‘political gender commissar’ was already taken.  The irony is, of course, that you can’t have your woke, gender mainstreaming cake and eat it too. What’s the point of quotas anyway if gender is a fluid concept? If you, like I do, believe that merit, not identity politics, should be at the heart of recruitment policy, then vote against this report.

name: Έλενα Κουντουρά
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work and colleagues for his excellent cooperation. Today's vote on this report on the promotion of gender equality in the European Union's foreign and security policy coincides with the 20th anniversary of the historic adoption of UN Resolution 1325 on women, peace and security. Twenty years on, despite the progress made, women still suffer significant inequalities and injustices. They continue to be under-represented in foreign policy, particularly in positions of responsibility and decision-making centres, and this weakens our ability to ensure sustainable peace and build more resilient societies.  This progressive report will be our response as the European Parliament to promoting equality in European foreign policy by strengthening equal representation, defending women's rights and ensuring adequate financial resources for this purpose. Integrating the gender dimension into the European Union's migration and trade policy, combating trafficking, which particularly affects women and children, ensuring the European Union's continued cooperation and genuine support for women's organisations and human rights defenders, actively supporting sexual and reproductive health in third countries, promoting the active participation of women in peace processes and improving the framework for supporting women in the new GAP III Equality Action Plan. For us these are not just questions of justice, but determinants of a world with more security, solidarity and democracy.

name: Pernille Weiss (PPE).
text: – Mr President, 'what people have the capacity to choose, they have the ability to change.' That's what Us Former Secretary of State Madeleine Albright has said. In fact, it is very clear to hear that she is European. That is why, in the European Parliament, we can also choose to do what we cannot or cannot accept for others to accept. That is why, of course, the EPP is voting in favour of the EU stepping up for more focus on gender equality in our foreign and security policy. In our own institutions and not least in the way we engage in the world. That is why, as shadow rapporteur, I have emphasised the tools that work and bring about change. For me, and for the EPP, the will ingness and the demand for equality is natural and indispensable. It is above gender and many other more or less modern categories of identity and politically correct language. That is why it is also wrong that an equality-oriented security and foreign policy should perhaps in future be called 'feminist'. I do not agree with the very part of the report on which we are going to vote, but I would like to acknowledge that we have to cooperate with Mr Urtasun. We have agreed on most things, and the rest we live with in respect of the democratic culture, which we would just like to express more clearly through the future defence and security policy of the European Union. Namely, that regardless of gender and everything else, the rule applies: equal access, equal opportunities, equal rights and equal treatment. And may I not conclude with the fact that Madeleine Albrigt has also said and is best known for saying: 'there is a special place in hell for women who don't help other women'. I am not going to stand here and threaten anyone, even the men, but I hope that everyone will vote in favour of the report.

name: Robert Biedroń (S&D).
text: – Mr President, since this great report stresses that EU foreign and security policy is dominated by men, it’s crucial to engage them – us – in gender equality activities. Boys and men have a special role to play in promoting the empowerment of girls and women. Why? Because we men still – unfairly, of course – keep the power and so hold the key to solving the problem. Achieving gender equality is not possible without the inclusion and active involvement of men and boys in the process of making progress on gender equality. Men and boys must be invited to participate and contribute actively in promoting health and gender norms. Some might ask ‘why?’ Because besides bringing equality, it improves the health of families and economic well-being. Let me stress the words my colleague Madeleine Albright just said (and I paraphrase): there is a special place in hell for men who don’t help women.

name: Virginie Joron (ID).
text: Mr President, first of all, I wanted to congratulate the staff in Strasbourg and Brussels who were able to organise a remote plenary in perfect conditions. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to start by paying tribute to Samuel Paty, who was beheaded because he wanted to teach freedom of expression in France in 2020. The best tribute we can pay to him and to all those who died of Islamist terrorism is to fight and eradicate Islamism. Today's debate is about gender equality in the European Union's foreign policy. Since the European Union is so eager to always lead by example, it is legitimate to ask what example Europe and France really give to the rest of the world. Is it with Axelle, hit and dragged for 800 meters by a young man while she was walking her dog? Is it with Mya, beaten by three young people? With 15-year-old C., raped, strangled and burned by a repeat rapist while she was picking up a package? Or Mila, harassed and threatened with death? These barbarities are growing at the same rate as the arrival of migrants in Lesbos or Lampedusa. Equally numerous are forced or early marriages, excision and virginity certificates for women. Obscure practices that have recently arrived with these waves of migration who don't care about your 40-page equality reports to gain access to boards of directors. Instead of letting the European Union get involved in foreign policy issues, I think that Europe must first put its own house in order and protect all its daughters before it wants to impose its egalitarian ideology on the other side of the world.

name: Margarita de la Pisa Carrión (ECR).
text: – Mr President, gender ideology is an assault on sanity, a virus that aims to get into all areas, infecting laws and institutions, deconfiguring one's reality and creating a victimistic culture without meaning or hope, as is the case in this report, which mixes very important and serious issues, such as aspects affecting human rights — trafficking in sex slaves , female genital mutilation, marriage of girls—with gender theories at the service of other power interests, manipulating consciences, and presented as a wolf with lambskin.  In this way, instead of inspiring, we export out of our borders philosophies and models that confront and polarize relations between men and women, causing conflict, hatred and resentment. We only offer abortion as a source of progress.  We want our foreign and security policy to reflect the principles and values that gave rise to the European project, without falling into false fashion theories that cloud human consciousness, preventing a culture from releasing its best expression.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: As you can see, the innovation of this plenary continues with great success: to have the right of colleagues to speak remotely. I think we should credit this to the European Parliament, which combines security in the context of the pandemic with the smooth functioning of the institution of parliamentary democracy called the European Parliament.

name: Lina Gálvez Muñoz (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the importance of this report on gender equality in the european Union's foreign and security policy, for which I congratulate Ernest Urtasun, lies mainly in three issues.  First, there is still an under-representation of women in the positions of representation and management of Community foreign policy. Second, differentiated socialization, the historical linkage of the feminist movement with the pacifist movement has always made women's participation in conflict resolution more linked to life, more linked to peace. Therefore, this differentiated vision is necessary. And third, because these conflicts affect us unequally with women, and our voices need to be heard. This day coincides with the 20th anniversary of UN Resolution 1325 on women, peace and security. And twenty years later, if we look at what is happening in Belarus, we find that women continue to face conflict resolution in a differentiated, much more pacifist way, embodying the values of democracy and harmony that we want to remain the values that represent the European Union.  It is therefore very necessary that we make progress precisely in the inclusion of gender equality in our foreign policy.

name: Elżbieta Kruk (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The declared aim of this report is to increase the participation of women in European foreign policy, which, I recall, is and should be a competence of the Member States. Analysis of the content of the report indicates that it is in fact an expression of the ideology of constant division of people, which dictates that they be serialed according to gender, racial and, God deigns to know what else. There is so-called positive discrimination invented for levee feminism and ordering the favouritism of one sex at the expense of another. However, simply declaring that gender plays a role is pure discrimination.  And it's just important that all people have the same opportunities. Competent persons should be in the right place because of their predisposition. It should be noted that favouring a group not only reduces the degree of motivation, but also diminishes its value and conflicts with an elementary sense of equality and justice. I think that this pretend concern for women is to cover up the fact that all these efforts for equality are just a game of power, which the left cultivates on the principle of 'divide and rule'.

name: Vladimír Bilčík (PPE).
text: – Mr President, today we have a debate on foreign policy and it has to be said that the position of women in foreign policy in the European institutions is quite a success story. Yes, there is always much to improve, but even in the European Parliament itself, women play a strong role in our external relations in the leadership of delegations or of Parliament itself. The problem of gender equality in European foreign policy is elsewhere. In several Member States, including the Central European region and my own country, Slovakia. If we really want to change the position of women in European foreign policy, changes must come, especially in those parts of Europe where gender equality is far from working as it does in the Brussels institutions. In foreign policy, we need strong role models that will motivate the work on gender equality. When was the last time you heard of a head of diplomacy in the Visegrad Four countries? If you can't think of a name, it's no coincidence. All the more so today, girls and young women in Central Europe can motivate the success story of The Slovak President Zuzana Čaputová. However, successful gender equality cannot stand only on inspirational stories and favourable circumstances. It is and must be about practical measures that will support the functioning of family life or pre-school childcare, so that my daughter's generation has equal hope of leading diplomacy in Central Europe, so that the debate on gender equality in European foreign policy has a strong practical basis across the Member States.

name: Heléne Fritzon (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Thank you, Commissioner Urpilainen, for a very progressive introduction. 2020 would be a super year for gender equality. It is 25 years since the Beijing Declaration and it is 20 years since the UN Security Council adopted the resolution on women and security. But instead of a strong year for gender equality, we have had a pandemic that shifts the focus, while at the same time affecting the human rights of women and girls. This applies not least to access to sexual and reproductive health and rights.  It's high time we set things up. The EU needs to ensure a gender perspective in all areas. I want to see an end to discrimination against women and girls worldwide. My country, Sweden, and my government have had a feminist foreign policy since 2014 and now, now it is the EU's turn.

name: Antonius Manders (PPE).
text: – Mr President, equal treatment starts with yourself. This has to do with the freedom we have in our culture and with education and civilisation. I therefore wholeheartedly support this resolution, and I see the need for attention to be paid to equal treatment for men and women, because in practice it appears that there is still no equal treatment outside Europe, but also within Europe. I call on anyone who finds discrimination against women or men or any other discrimination to report it directly to the organisations responsible. And possibly, if those organisations do not want to act, to the media, to create enough pressure to eliminate that discrimination. In this case, I would like to draw attention to a form of discrimination that I have seen in one of the largest organisations in the perhaps greatest side line in the world, namely football, UEFA and FIFA. When I see Champions League football matches, I see the European flag. Next, I look at fifa's rules. And that's where women's football is being discriminated against! It is literally in Article 20 of those regulations. I have written to FIFA on that. And what turns out? They answer and say, Mr. Manders, we know that. So they say literally: we know that and we have set up a study group to see if we need to change it and see if it is in favour of women's football that we are eliminating that discrimination! I call on the Commission and all Members to do something about this. Please write a letter to FIFA that they are amending Article 20!

name: Tanja Fajon (S&D).
text: – Dear President! Today we are talking about women, about their indispensable role in resolving conflicts and building peace. The debate is very important to strengthen gender equality in foreign policy, including in responding to the coronavirus epidemic.  Around the world, women and girls are most vulnerable to violence, so the European Union must do much more. We call on the High Representative of the Union to invest more financial resources to encourage women's training so that they become more involved in humanitarian situations.  Gender should not be an obstacle. Women and girls are often exposed to sexual violence in crisis areas, which is also used as a military tactic. Women must no longer be victims, peace takes much longer if women are also involved in peace negotiations. Today, less than 10% are involved.  Let us ensure parity, provide them with conditions if we are indeed defenders of women's rights in Europe.  We want binding measures, this year we are marking the anniversary from Beijing and the United Nations resolution on women's rights.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE).
text: – Mr President, women remain largely unrepresented and undervalued in politics and the decision—making process in the EU and beyond. Nonetheless, the European Union has committed to the United Nations Sustainable Development Goal to promote and achieve gender equality. This also counts for our foreign and security policy. Aside from the aspect of equal representation, women’s participation also has an added value. Studies show that our contribution to peace negotiations has led to long—lasting peace agreements and improved human security. We can see some progress as almost all EU delegations have carried out a detailed gender analysis and the number of women deployed to security and defence missions and operations has increased, but we are still far from reaching a real balance. As the PPE shadow rapporteur for the Committee on Foreign Affairs (AFET) opinion to this report, I welcome the guidelines on gender mainstreaming for EU civilian missions and call to extend this concept to all other relevant missions, departments and delegations related to our foreign policy. Only in this way can we fully promote recognition of the significant role women play at the local, national and international levels. To conclude, I would like to call on the High Representative and the Commission to intensify their actions to reach our ambition of a gender balance by the end of the mandate. Gender mainstreaming requires not only high—level policy statements but also a real political commitment.

name: Jutta Urpilainen
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I want to thank Members for this very, very good and interesting discussion. Women’s meaningful participation in all matters related to foreign and security policy has a wider relevance to the central role of the European Union in contributing to efforts to achieve peace, security and sustainable development. The action plan will enable us to walk that talk by putting resources where our priorities are, including by reiterating our commitment that 85% of all new EU actions promote gender equality as a significant or principal objective. I would also like to re-confirm that the Commission and the External Action Service attach great importance to ensuring equal opportunities and diversity of staff in management positions and we are already taking concrete steps to this end. Within the Commission, the gender equality strategy adopted earlier this year gives concrete steps to reach 50-50 equal gender balance in management positions at the Commission. At the External Action Service, the work is jointly done with the Member States as, by nominating one third of the staff, they have a direct contribution to our objective. Today, men hold 66% of middle management positions and 74% of senior management posts, while almost 27% of the heads of delegations are women. Although this is an improvement, I fully agree with the Members on the need to further promote gender balance in the EU’s external representation and reach full equality. This will be addressed as part of the Gender Action Plan (GAP) III, and work is already ongoing to work towards a similar target as for the Commission. Mr President, putting women and young people in the driving seat of the recovery: I strongly believe this will be the most effective way to collectively respond to the global challenges that we are facing worldwide at this very critical moment of our human history. (Applause)

name: Ernest Urtasun
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to start by thanking everybody who contributed to our debate. I think that the debate showed that there is a broad majority in Parliament behind what we are going to adopt tomorrow, and this is extremely good news. I would also like to thank the Commissioner for her words and for being with us. Hannah Neumann and I liked a lot her mention that she wants to build a gender—responsive and geopolitical Commission. We liked that approach a lot. I think this is one of the good conclusions of our debates. But I think in general that we are all worried about the backlash on women’s rights that is happening all around the world, and that is really something that needs to be an additional motivation for us, to push for this feminist foreign policy that we all want. Three things before I come to an end.  Firstly, as you mentioned, Madam Commissioner, I think that the Neighbourhood, Development and International Cooperation Instrument (NDICI) Regulation is going to be an important tool to achieve gender equality and an important instrument for us. I hope that in the negotiations the targets on gender equality will remain as high as proposed. This is one of the key issues in the coming months.  Secondly, I think it’s important to say that the commitment to improve the presence of women both in the EEAS, in the Commission, and in our delegations is an important target.  I would like to remind the House that the High Representative has committed to the 40% target of EU heads of delegation by the end of the term. I think that it should be a joint goal to achieve that, and so I’m very much looking for the actions that that you will be undertaking and, of course, we will be very attentive to the presentation of GAP III in November, which is going to be the most important tool that we will have to achieve all of these goals.  So, all in all, I just want to conclude by thanking everybody, thanking the Commissioner. Let’s make a gender—responsive Commission and gender—responsive EU foreign and security policy a reality.

name: Didier Reynders
text: Member of the Commission. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, to begin with, I would like to reiterate what commission president Ursula von der Leyen strongly said last month in her State of the Union address to this Parliament: European values are not for sale. Unfortunately, this statement does not seem as obvious as it should be throughout the Union. Some Member States have, in fact, put in place systems in place to enable wealthy investors and their family members to obtain a passport in exchange for payment of a large sum of money or a substantial investment, without having a real connection with the Member State in question. Such programmes have obvious implications for all other Member States and for the Union as a whole. Indeed, becoming a national of a Member State automatically entails obtaining EU citizenship and all related rights. A foreign investor who buys the nationality of an EU Member State can, on this basis, immediately go to any other Member State, engage in economic activity and benefit from the principle of non-discrimination between European citizens in a range of areas. He can even participate in the democratic process, notably through the exercise of his right to vote and the right to be a candidate in European or municipal elections. For several years now, these programmes have been a source of great concern, notably for this House and the Commission. The Commission has worked hard on this matter, as it is also a European issue with European values at stake. In January 2019, the Commission published its first-ever report on investor citizenship schemes and investor residence schemes operated in the EU. The report clearly spelled out the inherent risks of such schemes, in particular as regards security, money laundering, tax evasion and corruption. Since the beginning of this Commission's mandate, we have continuously raised this concern with the Member States concerned, urging them to reconsider their decision to operate such schemes.  Since the beginning of my mandate, I have had a constant dialogue with the relevant Member States where I repeatedly highlighted the Commission's concerns and urged them to reconsider their decision to operate such schemes. Before the pandemic, I put personally with the Ministers of the relevant Member States to discuss investor citizenship schemes. In April, I followed up with letters asking to reconsider the schemes. I also had several calls with the competent Ministers to follow up on their commitments to provide more information on their government's plan. While both Malta and Cyprus may have the intention to apply some changes to their investor citizenship schemes, they appear to be determined to continue their schemes in some form. We need to convince them not to do that. Ladies and gentlemen, a series of recent scandals in Cyprus and Malta only confirm the serious concerns we have already expressed. In its report, the Commission pledged to monitor the compliance of existing regimes with EU law and, if necessary, to take the necessary measures. Today I am here to tell you that the Commission is keeping this commitment. The Commission decided this week to open infringement proceedings against the investment citizenship programmes set up by Cyprus and Malta. EU citizenship is a collection of shared rights that all Member States provide in solidarity. Together, the Member States create the conditions for the enjoyment of EU citizenship. The European Court of Justice has been clear: it is for each Member State to lay down the conditions for the acquisition and loss of nationality. But, as the Court has also ruled, this jurisdiction must be exercised having due regard for EU law.  EU law requires Member States to recognize the nationality of another Member State without imposing any other conditions. As a result, the decision to naturalize a person by a Member State is not limited to its own jurisdiction and is not neutral with regard to other Member States. Member States should, therefore, use their prerogatives to grant nationality with due regard for EU law and, in particular, to the principle of sincere cooperation which is laid down in the Treaties. A Member State fails in that obligation when it establishes a scheme that systematically grants naturalization in the absence of any true link with the state and on the sole basis of a financial investment or, in other words, where passports are for sale.  Over the span of only a couple of years, Cyprus and Malta have naturalized several thousand people based on their schemes. The price for a European passport in those Member States range between EUR 1 million and EUR 2 million. These investor citizenship schemes undermine the mutual trust of Member States in each other's naturalization procedures. This trust is a precondition for the effective enjoyment of EU citizenship rights. By undermining this trust, these schemes threaten the integrity of EU citizenship and its proper functioning and violate the principle of sincere cooperation. Ladies and gentlemen, Malta seems to have committed itself to replacing the current regime with a new programme, on a seemingly largely unchanged basis. In Cyprus, while the government has announced the end of the current regime in the near future, the implementation of a new programme is already being discussed. But the issue is too important to wait for the outcome of this process. We are now taking steps to show our determination and commitment not to accept eu citizenship as a mere convenience. I think we can all agree on one important point: the principles and values of the Union are weakened if membership of the European project, the rights that flow from it and participation in its democratic life are the subject of a simple economic transaction. Let me also add a couple of words on Bulgaria, which also operates an investor citizenship scheme. This week, the Commission sent a letter to the Bulgarian authorities strongly urging them to phase out their scheme in the context of an ongoing national legislative procedure to change the Bulgarian citizenship law. We have also asked for additional information on the scheme. The Commission will not hesitate to consider an infringement procedure against Bulgaria if necessary. Finally, the Commission has not forgotten about schemes that give foreign investors access to residence permits, also called 'golden visas'. While golden visa schemes do not raise the same legal issues as schemes that result in the acquisition of EU citizenship, there is often a close interaction between the two types of scheme, as residence can be a prerequisite for the acquisition of nationality. Most of the inherent risks of such schemes, for example regarding security, money laundering and corruption, are the same. Third-country nationals with a valid EU residence permit can travel freely, in particular in the Schengen area. This means that if one Member State does not apply the necessary security checks, other Member States can be negatively affected. Member States should therefore ensure that all the necessary steps are taken to prevent security, corruption, tax evasion and money laundering risks. They must also apply rigorous and transparent criteria to identify and fight crime and corruption.  The Commission has expressed its concern about the risks inherent in residence schemes and about the fact that these risks are not always sufficiently mitigated by the measures taken by Member States. In this context, the Commission continues to closely monitor these schemes and their application, to ensure compliance with EU law, including the need to carry out all obligatory border and security checks, in line with the EU acquired prior to the issuance of any permit.  The same applies to citizenship schemes run by third countries, including some candidate countries, which have visa-free access to the EU. Such access should not be used as a marketing tool to attract money in exchange for citizenship. Following the adoption of its January 2019 report, the Commission requested information and raised its concerns with all visa-exempt third countries that apply or plan investment citizenship programmes in close cooperation with the European External Action Service. As a result, some countries have already repealed their regimes and others have ended their plans. We will continue to monitor the issue closely to assess any potential security risks associated with these plans. In any case, I am delighted to have been able to explain the Commission's policy to your Parliament this morning and I would be very happy to take your comments, of course, and answer your questions.

name: Λουκάς Φουρλάς
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. Mr President, Commissioner, we are discussing a very serious issue here, on which we will have to make a number of assumptions, and I begin by saying this: the programme has had its weaknesses, which some have exploited and will have to take responsibility, apologise and pay the price. At the same time, we cannot ignore the fact that this programme was adopted by some countries, such as Cyprus, in response to the economic crisis. Do not forget, ladies and gentlemen, that Cyprus in 2013 became Europe's guinea pig by imposing the deposit haircut for the first and last time throughout Europe.  I would also like to add this: Cyprus has terminated — as you said, Commissioner — by a decision of the cabinet the programme, after it was found to have been exploited by deft people, possibly by an organised circuit. I repeat that the responsibilities exist and must be attributed to those who are theirs, no matter how high they may be. What I do not accept is the attempt by some to deliberately target Cyprus and its people at this extremely difficult time in my country because of Turkish aggression, for which some here do not show the same sensitivity. Our aim here must be, Commissioner, to tackle corruption, those involved in it and those who have broken the law and not to humiliate an entire people, who are currently fighting for survival. That is why we must be very careful.

name: Eero Heinäluoma
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, a new plenary, a new debate on money laundering and a tax scandal. This really is a very bad trend. At the same time, our voters are asking for just one thing: a fairer tax regime where everyone pays their fair share, and a society where money laundering cannot be a way for criminals to have a fast track to land in Europe. Golden visas: research shows that EU Member States have attracted around EUR 25 billion in foreign investment over the last 10 years thanks to golden visa programmes. Investments are important, but so are our values – today, more so than ever. Cyprus Leaks and the names revealed are worth discussing. With enough criminal money, you can buy legal entry to the European Union, and right-wing politicians in Cyprus seem happy to facilitate this. It’s a disgrace for the whole of the European Union. The contrast and indifference with respect to the burning Moria refugee camp could not be bigger. I agree with the Commission that these schemes pose risks for the Member States and for the Union, so this habit must end. In an equal Europe, there should be no room for golden visa programmes; EU passports and visas are not commodities. Therefore, Council Presidency, Commissioner, I urge you to get your acts together. Let’s ban these programmes completely. Let’s make Europe a better and safe place for ordinary people – not for criminals.

name: Sophia in ‘t Veld
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for coming here and for starting the infringement procedures. I think that is most welcome and we knew that it had been in the pipeline for quite some time. However, this House has been debating the problems with golden passport since 2014. Why did it take so long? Why did the authorities wait so long to intervene? Why did we have to wait for brave journalists to uncover the scandals that we all suspected for a long time? And some of these journalists have paid a very high price – the highest price, as we know. But journalists are not responsible for law enforcement. The authorities are, and the authorities are failing. Those who have a legitimate interest in investing in the European economy can do so without problem, and no golden passport nor golden visa scheme can ever really be clean and legitimate – because due diligence that relies on cooperation with the Russian and the Chinese and the Saudi authorities, frankly, can never be watertight – and I’m being polite here. Despite the fancy names of the schemes – you know ‘residency by investment’ sounds nice, evokes these images of villas and yachts, and what have you – in reality, they are just a golden backdoor into the European Union for criminals, criminals. It’s not investment; it is criminal money. Now, we need a full ban, and we’re calling on the European Commission, not for the first time, to propose legislation, and I’m proud to say that at the initiative of my group Renew Europe, the Committee for Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) Committee is going to draft a legislative initiative calling for a ban on golden passports. But of course this is a national competence. You know, national governments cannot sell what is not theirs to sell, and that is EU citizenship. It isn’t theirs, they cannot sell it. So are governments, is the Council finally also going to take responsibility, or will they continue to knowingly facilitate criminals? The final question, Commissioner: will you also address the ‘legacy’ of those who have already received a Cypriot or Maltese or other passport? Will there be a second screening to see what kind of people we have actually elevated to the status of EU citizen?

name: Dominique Bilde
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Mr President, first of all, I would like to make it clear that I am always happy to speak from the Strasbourg Parliament, where I hope that we will soon have the authorisation to return regularly to our plenary sessions. Is it any wonder that the Scandal of Cypriot golden visas, since the expensive acquisition of citizenship and residence permits could only serve crooked purposes? That Montenegro, once again providing such facilities, continues to lead the race for the next European enlargement demonstrates the Commission's indifference to a tangible security threat. These are not very good weapons that have not prevented Pakistan, the leader in such fraudulent documents, according to a British diplomat, from receiving 4 billion euros in European aid since 2014. The Union therefore deplores the effects which it cherishes the causes. First, his support for states and, in this case, avowed supporters of radical Islam. These visas, however, are only part of a juicy business that fuels the migratory flood like terrorism. This is evidenced by the possible sale of Bosnian visas to Pakistani migrants, while two pakistani nationals were allegedly suspected of terrorism, or the profile of the false minor who carried out the Paris attack.

name: Sven Giegold
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the The European passport is one of the most tangible results of European cooperation. It gives rights to all who have it, and therefore this right and passport must not be sold.  EU passports decide who has access to our citizens' rights and who does not. And if this decision is taken on the purse strings and not on who integrates into our societies, works here, lives here, then it is not the principle of European law that prevails, but the principle of the mafia. That is why it is also unacceptable for citizens' rights to be put up for sale.  It is not acceptable for an individual country to decide who has access to it, but then to be exposed to corresponding rights in all EU countries. This is how individual states collect billions of euros, which actually lead to consequences throughout Europe. That is why it is unacceptable that the European Commission has, in fact, done nothing for years. Conversely, however, I would like to thank you now for your initiative. These infringement procedures were overdue. At last, take on that - that's fine, that's right.  But you should not only consider the sale of passports, but also golden visas. The Portuguese programme, for example, has sold 25 000 golden visas over the last eight years for investments of more than EUR 5 billion, and this often leads to citizenship. And that is why we must not close our eyes. I therefore ask you, Commissioner, not to set double standards! Visas are not allowed to be sold either, not just passports. That is why this Parliament must present a legislative own-initiative report, with which we will also enforce this demand.  I would ask you, Commissioner, to update the data and your compilation of the programmes. The Commission's current websites say very little. Finally, which is not my passport, by the way, but that of my colleague Hanna Neumann, she lent it to me free of charge.

name: Joachim Stanisław Brudziński
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by There can be no place in Europe for criminals, criminals, terrorists or dictators, and passports, citizenship, visas cannot be goods. And that, unfortunately, it is a huge income branch for several European Union countries today, the figures show best. For Cyprus, this is as much as 5% of GDP. In 2017 only, the country's budget revenue stood at more than €1 billion. In Spain, around €976 million, Greece €250 million and Portugal around €700 million.  This poses a serious threat to the security of our countries and citizens. There are reports, such as al-Jazeera station, describing how easily and seamlessly criminals, including those associated with the Islamic State, are thus infiltrating member states. The fact that a trafficker, drug or human being or Islamic terrorist group has set up EUR 500 000 for property in Cyprus or EUR 350 000 in Malta is not really a major problem. And such amounts were spent in the case of those States in order to acquire citizenship which, I stress, allowed freedom of movement throughout the Union.  Therefore, it is extremely important to have the most rigorous security checks on applicants, with a particular focus on their criminal past.

name: Γιώργος Γεωργίου
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, Commissioner, the European Left has been very cautious about these programmes from the outset, mainly because of its concerns about money laundering, corruption and tax evasion. The GUE stresses that these programmes, particularly when they do not contain safeguards for channelling resources for social development, favour the rich and the circuits and not the ordinary people in the countries that implement them.  Commissioner, I am a Member of the European Parliament in Cyprus and I feel a double duty to stress the need to stop all these programmes, which have become morbid hotbeds of corruption and interconnection for circuits that trade in European citizenship or even for programmes that are becoming a way to the European Union for fraudsters from all over the world. I represent my people, the ordinary citizens of Cyprus, who have neither seen nor heard nor know about these things and it is unfair to target them. I admit, however, that the nationality programme in Cyprus has caused enormous problems on my island, particularly with the way it has been transformed and handled by the Government of Cyprus, which — unfortunately — has not listened to the European Commission's proposals to bring about the right changes. Thus, I convey the universal demand of Cypriot society for transparency and the fight against corruption at every level, throughout Europe.

name: Laura Ferrara (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, for several years now, the European business on passports and golden visas has been a well-known and growing phenomenon, and the Cyprus scandal is just the latest in a long line.  We have long allowed several Member States to make money from citizenship and residence rights, allowing them to price them, to exchange them for investments by wealthy foreign citizens. This market, which moves billions of euros, in which there are no common standard rules, is also able to take advantage of criminals and people who fuel corruption and want to launder huge wealth, often the result of illegal activities, by taking advantage of privileged tax regimes.  The European institutions have for years been expressing concerns about national programmes of residence and citizenship for investors in the European Union, but they only react decisively in the event of scandals that have been the subject of journalistic investigations, as happened recently with the news of activating infringement proceedings against Cyprus and Malta. The European Union cannot tolerate rights and values being listed, allowing criminals from third countries to obtain passports or visas with which to move freely within European territory, with serious consequences for internal security and leading to serious shortcomings in the fight against organised crime, money laundering, corruption, tax evasion and avoidance.  The European Union has a duty to put an end to the serious shortcomings of these programmes in terms of transparency and strict controls, safeguarding trust and the principle of loyal cooperation between Member States and preserving Europe's borders from financially available criminals.

name: Jeroen Lenaers (PPE).
text: – Mr President, golden passport, it sounds almost sympathetic, a bit like the golden wrappers from Charlie and the chocolate factory. But in that book we are already warned by Roald Dahl that unwanted people with a lot of money can simply appropriate such a ticket, with all the consequences that entails. That's annoying for a chocolate factory. It is simply dangerous for a European Union. So let's stop that euphemism, golden passport, and let's just call the critter by its name. Not a gold passport but a fraud passport! A rich Russian or Chinese who scatters his dubious money and registers at a petrol station in Malta is suddenly an EU citizen, with all the privileges and benefits that go with it. But benefits and privileges for rich Chinese and Russians, for rich criminals, the risks are for all of us: security risks, money laundering, tax evasion, corruption, circumvention of EU rules, risks that we in this house have been warning about for years. It is therefore good that the European Commission is finally taking steps. Better late than never, shall we say. But infringement proceedings against two small Member States are not enough! We need really strict and clear rules for the future to ensure that these types of fraud passports are actually made impossible across the EU. An EU passport, that is the main conclusion, is a privilege and not a commodity. It is time for us all to act on this.

name: Paul Tang (S&D).
text: – Mr President, over the years, millions risked their lives to gain an EU passport. If they only had 20 million! In fact, for that money, Cyprus would have welcomed them with open arms. In fact, Cyprus welcomed some of the very same people responsible for others fleeing their home. They welcomed the cousin of Assad, they welcomed the associates of Hun Sen, the dictator of Cambodia, and they welcomed known criminals and gave them safe access to the entire EU, so the EU is fully justified in taking action, and I applaud the Commission’s infringement procedure. Better late than never. But these alone won’t do the trick. Criminals looking for a safe haven in the EU will find our weakest spots: today, Cyprus and Malta, tomorrow, Montenegro and Austria. This is why we need clear minimum requirements for citizenships and for residency. This means an end to fast—track procedures. This means – at least – strong anti—money laundering safeguards to ensure funds were legally obtained and this means clear requirements for the kind of investments allowed, investments that indeed require you to actually be here. Most of all, instead of handing passports to criminals, I’d say we should save our passports for their victims.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa (Renew).
text: – Mr President, they say that good news is not news, but when it comes to a decision that makes things more difficult for the great evasors and criminals, I certainly think it is very good news. And I want it to be known in my country in Spain that the European Commission is finally going to initiate infringement proceedings against Cyprus and Malta for the sale of passports to non-EU persons.  For the Members - some of us here - who are part of the previous legislature of the Committee of Inquiry on the Roles of Panama, it is not only good but necessary news.  It is not just a game of advantage to take money for selling the highest bidder the residence or opening the door to the citizens of a country that brings down European citizenship and freedom of movement and business. It's just that it's wrong, it's disloyal; it is a coladero for friends of dictators and criminals, poisons our democracies and facilitates networks of corruption.  The so-called Cyprus Papers speak of convicts of fraud and money laundering, public figures and politicians accused of corruption. There are no excuses: we need proven data.  And, of course, it is essential to launch a review of suspicious awards, to review national investment-accelerated award systems, especially those where there is no requirement for physical residence. And if Bulgaria has to be apprehended and if it has to be sanctioned, let it be; and if my country has to be sanctioned, let it be.  Commissioner, to clear the playing field, you will have our support.

name: Bernhard Zimniok (ID).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Trade in nationalities such as those practised by Cyprus, Malta and other EU countries serves as a gateway for rich criminals in the EU. Interpol has stated that these passports are, in addition to money laundering, "very valuable for terrorists and international criminals who use them to cross undetected borders." A parallel with the EU's migration policy is obvious. While the less rich enter the EU by throwing away their own passports and, as is often the case, sneak ingesth down to multiple identities, in the case of golden passports, it is the rich who come to the EU by purchasing a passport. Both are illegal, but only one seems to disturb the EU, the other is being promoted. As long as the EU fails to enforce its laws across Europe, protest is only one – pathetic hypocrisy. Both, the trade in passports and entry without a passport, are prohibited.

name: Charlie Weimers (ECR).
text: – Mr President, deciding who enters, settles or becomes a citizen is a fundamental right of a sovereign state, but the Cypriot and Maltese golden passport schemes do not require a person to first live in the country before granting citizenship and the right to enter and settle in other European countries. The former Maltese Prime Minister’s Chief of Staff was arrested last month as part of an investigation into a kickback for a favourable passport decision scheme. To this debate, I’d like to add that the sale of visas is just as serious. Over two years have passed since 27 Members of this Parliament demanded an investigation into reports of mafia-style sales of visas – papers that enable free movement in Schengen countries. These should be common concerns. The sale of passports and visas is criminal; it impacts us all and it must end.

name: Rasa Juknevičienė (PPE).
text: – Mr President, our passports are not for sale. I come from a country where hundreds of thousands of people have died because of their right to be a citizen of their country and today, a citizen of the EU. EU citizenship is about a protection of the European way of life. It is about the security of our people, about our defence. It is about the duties of citizens. We must stop money launderers and other criminals that abuse the existing system. We must stop third countries from exploiting the system for their influence on operations. Therefore, all EU Member States must end all existing ‘citizenship by investment’ or ‘residency by investment’ schemes as soon as possible. I would also like to use the opportunity and to draw the Commission’s attention to a security loophole in the European visa-issuance system which enables third-country nationals with hostile intentions to enter the EU. Their abuse is possible partly due to their continued acceptance of non-biometric passports for travellers. I invite the EU to take immediate action to address this security gap in the European visa-issuance system.

name: Evin Incir (S&D).
text: – Mr President, as in a relationship, or any other kind of union, the basis of a functioning one is called trust. Welcoming criminals into our European Union with open arms, just because those criminals are rich, is totally outrageous and means forfeiting that trust because, regardless of what the Cypriot, Maltese, Bulgarian or any other government thinks, access to one EU country’s passport also means access to the whole EU, with all the benefits that it takes years for normal people to enjoy, even though they might have been exemplary inhabitants. This is not having sincere cooperation, nor is it upholding the integrity of what EU citizenship should mean. Convicted oligarchs and corrupt businessmen have nothing to do here in the EU.  I am glad that the Commission has at last started to be active on this matter, even though it has taken a long time – too long a time – but I also have a question as to why has it taken such a long time. My second question is also why doesn’t it include all the countries who have this kind of system in place, referring to the infringement process, of course. There are many reasons why one should be able to get an EU citizenship, but being rich and / or an oligarch aren’t two of them.

name: Jorge Buxadé Villalba (ECR).
text: – Mr President, welcome to this debate to highlight the inconsistencies of the Commission.  Because on the one hand they open a file for Hungary, Poland and the Czech Republic for not accepting false refugees, who then degsellate heads of teachers in France and yet they do open files to Cyprus or Malta for giving visas to investors without a link to the European Union. Welcome the genuine ties with Europe, but apply it to the whole immigration policy. Because what genuine ties do the thousands of migrants have on the shores of Algeria, Libya or Morocco? 2,600 illegals have been brought clandestinely by mafias in the last two weeks to the Canary Islands, more than in the whole past year.  Stop seeing everything in economic and financial terms. Stop saying that Europeans need thousands of migrants to pay pensions, because it's not true. Nations are not money. Nations are spiritual, family and cultural bonds of historical communities and must be respected. We don't want visas for speculators, drug dealers and mobsters. But we also don't want visas for those young soldiers who come to Europe to delinquery and fight us on the street.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, certainly the problem of the sale of passports to the so-called golden visas is important for the Union, but much more important is the problem of replacing the European population by bringing in migrants from Africa and the Middle East, referred to as politically correct refugees here. You, colleagues on the left of the chamber, support and continue to support the import of people into Europe. During the biggest immigration push, hundreds, perhaps thousands, of Islamic State fighters have emerged in Europe. Today they live here and wait for the moment when your extreme Marxism and liberal Bolshevism will lead to the collapse of European national states and they will see in this collapse a chance to establish their so-called " caliphate. I remind you of the nationality of the Islamist Chechen who beheaded the French professor. He had legal immigrant status, a refugee.  People applying for citizenship are educated, with professions and come from poorer countries to look for opportunities, which is what every Member State of the European Union offers. Remember that in order to issue a passport, a person is subject to a series of checks. The process is many times more complex and restrictive than getting an illegal refugee to obtain a residence document and freely cross the borders of the Union. The biggest and most severe problem is not several cases of purchased passports – each of them can be tracked and investigated. The biggest problem is that there are thousands of criminals, fighters of terrorist organizations who are untraceable and come here disguised as migrants and refugees. And it's your fault.

name: Didier Reynders
text: Member of the Commission. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you for sharing your views and concerns in this House. The Commission shares most of the comments that have been made, at least on the specific subject of passports and investment visas. The Commission has raised these concerns on a regular basis, including in this Parliament. Some of you might have wanted the Commission to launch infringement proceedings earlier. The Commission first tried to find a political solution on the basis of a dialogue with the Member States concerned, as I recalled. I have made the necessary contacts since last December to ask the States concerned to leave these programmes. The continuation of the programs in question now requires us to initiate infringement proceedings. The opening of infringement proceedings is the last step in efforts that have been ongoing for several years to address the concerns raised by monetary schemes that result in the acquisition of EU citizenship. The Commission encourages both Cyprus and Malta to continue their screening of successful applications that was launched following the recent scandals.  I know that there are many questions about the citizenship that Cyprus and Malta have already granted. In accordance with the applicable rules and respecting due processes, naturalization should be revoked wherever necessary. The question concerning retroactivities needs to be carefully assessed and it's premature to take a position on this now. We have not even gone to the Court of Justice and are even further away from a judgment, but we need to continue to have discussions about such issues. There were also some remarks about the need to finance the different budgets in the different Member States. Fostering investment is of course a legitimate goal for any country to pursue, in particular during these difficult times. However, this should not be done at any cost. EU citizenship is a collection of shared rights that all Member States provide in solidarity. Schemes that result in the selling of citizenship for the sole benefit of an individual Member State could be seen as exploiting this common achievement.  As you know, we have proposed a recovery plan of unprecedented size to protect lives and livelihoods, repair the single market and build a lasting and prosperous recovery. This is proof of strong European solidarity in the face of the enormous challenge our economies face. It would send the wrong signal if one Member State were seen to take economic measures that go against this solidarity among all Member States.  Ladies and gentlemen, the Commission will continue to uphold the values and rights of EU citizenship. You can count on his full commitment and my personal commitment to defending a common European citizenship, based on the principles of freedom, democracy, respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms and the rule of law. These values are not for sale and the Commission takes its responsibilities to avoid them being sold. We will continue to do so with regard to both passports and investment visas granted in the European Union, in candidate countries as well as in other third countries. Residence schemes, as I said in my introductory remarks, are different from citizenship schemes in terms of rights granted, but hacking similar risks. They are governed by national law but interact with EU law. The Commission will continue to monitor the situation closely, notably to ensure that the necessary border and security checks are carried out.  And I would like to conclude, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thanking you, not only for your attention, but above all for your support for the actions taken and to be taken in this area.
