name: Julie Lechanteux (ID)
text: In writing. Passports of convenience in the Member States of the European Union allow dubious figures to spread like a metastasis in the French or German social and economic fabric. A practice that must absolutely stop! A recent journalistic investigation into the sale of Cypriot passports, involving senior politicians, has sparked an unprecedented scandal in Nicosia. Indeed, since 2007, Cyprus has offered the possibility to wealthy non-European investors to obtain the famous "golden passport". These attribution procedures lack rigour and transparency, and are difficult to stop questionable investors. The system thus becomes an open door to tax evasion, money laundering, corruption and mafias from all walks of life. In Cyprus, the European sesame ticket is 2 and a half million euros - the price of the investment that the non-European national must make to obtain citizenship of that country. Cyprus is obviously not the only European country to sell its passport, Malta is following suit. The expert group set up by the European Commission in January 2019 to study this phenomenon has never met in 2020.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. – Claims that the investment citizenship/visa programmes run by various Member States pose serious security threats would be more credible if placed in the context of cross-border criminality within the EU. OLAF and the Court of Auditors have repeatedly indicated the incidence of massive cross-border fraud in the Union’s flagship policies. This has led to their operations being tightened, not cancelled. The same could be done with respect to citizenship/visa programmes if necessary, such as by appropriate AML legislation. Allegations being made against these programmes bear no comparison to ongoing criminal abuses attached to the Union’s own policies.  Moreover, claims that the programmes contradict the EU’s values become less credible in the wider context of how all European states accord citizenship and residence rights. Some of those who most endorse the claims, have arrangements by which such rights are given widely, non-transparently and with minimal security clearance. Investment citizenship/visa programmes form part of the sovereign rights of Member States and are strictly outside the competences of the Union. Any treatment at EU level of their application can be legitimate only if it forms part of a deeper examination overall of how all states – big and small – accord residence and citizenship to non-EU nationals.

name: Ramona Strugariu (Renew)
text: in writing. – I would like to welcome the initiative of the Commission of launching the infringement procedures against Cyprus and Malta regarding their “golden passport” schemes, as well as of highlighting its concerns regarding an investor citizenship scheme operated by Bulgaria. Besides the investor citizenship scheme, 19 Member States, plus the United Kingdom are using investor residency schemes, which gives investors the chance to gain residency in a given country. These schemes are posing a serious threat to our security and the fight against money laundering, tax evasion and corruption and are undermining the essence of the European Union and the freedoms that come with citizenship and residence of a member state. A country like Cyprus should avoid raising the suspicion that they are not cooperating sincerely with the European institutions on other justice matters, such as its participation in the EPPO. Notably, it should move swiftly to appoint full time European delegated prosecutors, as this is a guarantee of independence of the EPPO. It is time to stop criminals from entering the European Union and never allow them to launder their money, if we really want to fight corruption efficiently.

name: Bettina Vollath (S&D)
text: Writing. – What do Ali Beglov, Pham Nhat Vu and Zhang Keqiang have in common? They are all wealthy, influential and pre-punished; and they are all Cypriot citizens. They bought all three of them. Quite legal. A Cypriot citizenship costs EUR 2.5 million. It's a little cheaper to get away with in Malta or Bulgaria. Six-figure sums are already sufficient to obtain an EU passport. The sums are paid by "investments" in the countries concerned. What exactly is being invested in and what are the requirements? Unclear. What is clear, however, is who makes use of such programs: people like Ali Beglov, Pham Nhat Vu and Zhang Keqiang. People who exchange money for EU citizenship. A one-off payment against protection against foreign prosecution and for all rights as citizens of the Union.  If you try to take a closer look at these programs, you may pay for it with your life. This is what happened to the Maltese investigative journalist Daphne Caruana Galizia, who had researched exactly this before her assassination. The sale of these 'golden passports' must finally come to an end! I am therefore pleased that the Commission has now opened infringement proceedings against Malta and Cyprus. So that no one can simply buy the EU's passport – and so that no one loses their life.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the Commission statement on the state of the Energy Union (2020/2825(RSP)). I would like to inform you that for all the discussions in this part-session there will be no catch-the-eye procedure and no blue card questions and comments on the application of the Rules of Procedure will be accepted.
