name: Kadri Simson
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I am honoured to present to you today the State of the Energy Union Report. Every year, it’s an opportunity to take stock of our energy policy and assess whether we are on track with implementing the energy union. The 2020 report is the first one since we launched our new sustainability and growth strategy, the European Green Deal. A well-functioning energy union is the necessary basis to deliver our climate commitment by 2050. Together with this report, I presented three key initiatives on 14 October: the renovation wave, the methane strategy and the Commission recommendations on energy poverty. The initiatives of the 14 October energy package are important stepping stones to reach our 2030 climate target plan. They will make sure that we seize the significant decarbonisation potential of buildings and address energy poverty in order not to leave anybody behind in the clean energy transition.  National energy and climate plans (NECPs) will also remain an important tool in achieving the minimum 55% reduction in greenhouse gases. Together with the State of the Energy Union, we also published a detailed assessment of the plans of each Member State. The final NECPs are complete, robust and ambitious. Our analysis shows that each Member State still has some work to do, especially on energy efficiency. But overall we are heading in the right direction and the plans demonstrate that Europe can meet ambitious climate targets. The Commission will ensure a clear and inclusive follow—up of those plans, including on the progress of implementation and the need to revise the level of ambition of NECPs to reflect a higher carbon emission reduction target for 2030. Let me now go back to the State of the Energy Union Report. This report provides an overview of the progress of the energy union across all its dimensions. I would like to focus on three areas today.  First, we know that delivering the higher climate ambition in the energy sector is a genuine investment challenge. The State of the Energy Union Report maps out the funding opportunities offered by the recovery and resilience facility and other EU instruments. In particular, the Annual Sustainable Growth Strategy identified three energy-related flagships – clean energy technologies, renovation and sustainable transport – where Member States can focus their national renovation plans.  This shows that Next Generation EU offers an unprecedented opportunity to mobilise resources to promote the clean and digital transformation of our economies, and we should use it. The report, however, shows that national budgets devote a declining share to clean energy research and innovation. When we measure the volumes of research funding as a share of GDP, Europe has one of the lowest rates among the major global players. Private sector investment in energy union R&T priorities is also slowing down and I’m very concerned by this trend. Second, the report shows that the volume of energy subsidies, in particular for fossil fuels, is still considerable. Fossil fuel subsidies amounted to EUR 50 billion in the EU in 2018. This is one third of all our energy subsidies. The European Green Deal is clear: fossil fuel subsidies have to end. They remain a major impediment to a cost-efficient energy and climate transition, but also to a functioning internal market. Therefore, the Commission will reinforce its cooperation with Member States to phase out fossil fuel subsidies and reduce fossil fuel consumption. Energy subsidies should be targeted to boost the uptake of new energy technologies, to promote sustainable patterns of energy consumption, and to lower energy bills. Third, this year’s State of the Energy Union included for the first time a report on the competitiveness of the clean energy industry in Europe. The findings are quite significant. The growth of the clean energy technology sector has significantly outpaced that of the conventional energy sector. Clean energy technologies have created more jobs and added more to gross domestic product and labour productivity. This has been especially obvious in energy efficiency, where the number of jobs went up 17.4% between 2000 and 2017.  The Competitiveness Report also shows that EU industry holds a strong global position in some of the key technologies, namely offshore solar energy storage, batteries and hydrogen technologies, which have a major scaling-up potential over the coming years. In the coming months, we will take these elements forward and we will focus in our discussions with all relevant stakeholders on a value-chain-based approach to support our industries and innovators in the EU to maintain or achieve global success. I will stop here and now I will take your questions.

name: Markus Pieper
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the Thank you to the Commissioner for this report. This report states – and this is a good thing – that we have already exceeded CO2 targets by 2020. It is also great that we decouple economic growth from energy consumption. Thank you also for this positive outlook. We are in the midst of the energy transition. However, we must not make mistakes now, especially in the Corona crisis. Allow me, therefore, to put a question to the Commission: when we discussed the same report last year, it was said, and I quote: 'The clean energy package forms a credible path to meeting its Paris agreement commitments', quote End. Why, 12 months ago, Paris still had 40% CO2 reduction swelled enough, and even the targets for lorries and cars were positively highlighted 12 months ago, and I quote, as 'ambitious policies on climate mobility'. I do not find this answer in the 2020 report – just a reference to the fact that it must now be at least 55%. Parliament even wants 60%. I am also in favour of stronger standards, but it is like in medicine: a lot does not necessarily help much, and too much harms.  Yes, our people and businesses are on their way to Paris, but they need planning certainty, not erratic, sometimes panicked arbitrariness. Instead of pushing the targets ever higher, we need to think carefully about the way forward. For example, the report says that Covid—19 exacerbates the problem of energy poverty. Now comes the renovation base. What can we expect tenants to do? The pandemic and higher carbon pricing?  The report says that new energy infrastructure is the key to a successful energy transition, but the Commission announces new rights of action for NGOs and environmental associations. We have to decide: do we want a rapid energy transition with modern infrastructures, with great impact, positive for biodiversity, or do we want to save a bat family because an NGO—complaint requires it?' We do not need new rights of action. We need faster, unbureaucratic approval procedures and we need to make the COVID funds Recovery Fund more binding for the energy transition. We are on the right track, but please do not overturn the screw of the climate commitment, then it will break.

name: Nicolás González Casares
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, Commissioner, the Energy Union is crucial and important to our economy and our transition to climate neutrality and, to be a reality, Europe must commit to solving the bottleneck it has. There is no union without interconnection and, for example, the Iberian Peninsula is isolated in this respect.  We see that the emission reduction targets for 2020 will be met. Let us hope that it is not a mirage also derived from the pandemic and remember that we still have 34 million Europeans who suffer from energy poverty and cannot adequately heat their homes.  The report also shows that we are losing strength in research and development in Europe compared to other blocks; we must promote them, we are lowering the number of patents.  Commissioner, Parliament has just set its commitment to a reduction of 60%, we have a strong will. I believe that the Commission's work programme is ambitious for advancing the Green Pact.  We have all the matters quite on track; let's push them a little more and not let ourselves be overcome by the skepticism or the economic damage that this pandemic is causing.

name: Morten Petersen
text: renew group. Mr. President. Thank you to the Commissioner for a fine report that shows that the European Union must lead the way in the green transition and that we must do something now and that it is urgent. We have to deliver. We need more renewable energy across national borders. A genuine internal energy market will make it easier and cheaper to integrate renewable energy, for example from offshore wind farms out in the North Sea and into European power outlets, thus displacing fossil fuels from our energy supply. That is why the off-shore strategy is becoming so important, the one we are waiting for with excitement, Commissioner. The investments from the whole reconstruction package must be green. In Europe as a whole, we must build a competitive, green renewable energy industry and ensure that our green businesses are world class and that they remain world class. We must create a more integrated and efficient energy system so that citizens can get green and affordable energy. The 'refuse collection wave' is a very good initiative that creates jobs and combats climate change at the same time, but it must be ambitious so that we can renovate two to three times more buildings than what we manage to do today. And then we cannot escape having to revise some of the directives already on the table on renewable energy, energy efficiency, buildings and the role of buildings. And those directives must have higher and more ambitious objectives and binding targets for the Member States. According to the International Energy Agency, up to half of global green investments should be directed towards energy efficiency. At the same time, commissioner, we must ensure that the Member States deliver. So they're not doing that at the moment. I would urge the Commissioner to turn the screw on the Member States. If the Commission does not do so in the coming year, then we will fail the green transition. We voters owe it not to the electorate to do that. It's urgent, so let's get started!

name: Markus Buchheit
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Mr President, I would like to thank the Thank you, Commissioner, also for your presentation earlier. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she The Energy Union could indeed have become, or could have been, a project that would bring the benefits of EU-wide cooperation between the member states to the citizens and which could finally take the wind out of the sails of the critics of the Brussels Moloch, for example, for example. Instead, unfortunately, the Commission is blowing, as planned and aimless, it sometimes seems to be the hymn of terms from the bingo vocabulary of non-worldly ideologues, rather than addressing the real problems of citizens and businesses – in other words, instead of pursuing realpolitik.  Security of supply, economic efficiency and sustainability, that was the triad of energy policy of the past decades, and in fact these terms are, of course, also found within the Energy Union project. Paper is just patient, and reality speaks a different language. Over the past ten years, the price of electricity for private households in Germany has risen by almost 28%, network charges by 26%, and taxes and levies by as much as 65%. The Bild newspaper already has a heating cost shock in the coming year, when gasoline and diesel prices will also explode due to rising taxes. Economy, therefore, one of the three above-mentioned elements – misreporting. The frequency of near-blackouts has also increased rapidly in recent years, with the increase in the amount of green energy previously invoked. Germany, for example, has increasingly had to import electricity from neighbouring countries, often at horrendous costs. There can therefore be no question of security of supply.  And what about the much-vaunted sustainability? This, too, is a term from the vocabulary that has been falling over and over again today. In Germany, 6 000 wind turbines will be decommissioned this year alone. Up to 4 million tonnes of waste, some of which are toxic and difficult to dispose of, are produced. The same applies to solar energy, where we can expect around 2.6 million tonnes of scrap by 2035. As you can see, the current conditions of the so-called Energy Union do not meet economic principles, they do not meet the principles of security of supply, and certainly do not meet the mantra-like sustainability. It is time for us in this House, too, to finally recognise that our solidarity and responsibility must apply to the citizens, not to the Commission and the spirit of the times.

name: Ville Niinistö
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, the State of the Energy Union report highlights both the successes and the failures of the European Union in this field. We have over-achieved the energy targets for renewable energy for 2020, but obviously these targets are still modest. Now when Parliament is pushing for a higher ambition of 60% emission reductions by 2030, we have to look for a similar target for renewable energy to hasten the energy transition and also to make sure that it is European industries that create those jobs in energy revolution.  But there are also a lot of failures and one is obviously the increasing amount of fossil fuel subsidies. We still have in 2018 even more subsidies for fossil fuels than in 2015. The EUR 50 billion we are using on fossil fuel subsidies is three times more than the amount that we are spending on wind power in 2018. So the Commission has to force change in this field and has to make sure that the Member States get rid of fossil fuel subsidies, as Parliament has pushed for.

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I also wanted to ask for public aid for energy in general. Indeed, according to that report, this public aid has increased over the last decade. It amounted to €159 billion in 2017, although the Commission has long announced that it intends to eliminate this aid.  We know that growth in different sectors varied very differently, e.g. transport received 20% more subsidies in 2018 than three years earlier. Subsidies vary from country to country. If I read the table well, Germany spent almost €45 billion of public money on energy subsidies in 2018, of which it spent €12 billion on fossil fuels, which amounted to 1.2% of GDP. France, Italy and Belgium, too, subsidise fossil fuels much more in absolute terms than, for example, Poland, which is often portrayed as a country hampering the energy transition. Poland has allocated €2 billion and 0.2% of GDP to fossil fuels.  I would therefore like to ask what the Commission intends to do to reduce subsidies in the near future. How does it intend to do this in relation to different sectors? And how do these growing and varied subsidies, depending on the economic potential of the countries, go to the Green Deal and to the principles of just transition?

name: Marisa Matias
text: gue/NGL Group. Thank you, Commissioner, for your presentation. Of course, the energy transition is fundamental in combating climate change and job creation, but I would like to question energy poverty today and the refurbishment of buildings.  The European Commission's energy poverty strategy that has now been presented is a strategy that greatly improves our approach to this issue. However, I believe that it lacks some important dimensions. We know that in the poorest households in the European Union, energy bills account for almost 10% of monthly income. We also know from a number of times that exist that we are talking about tens of millions of citizens living in energy poverty in the European Union – there are reports pointing to more than 50 million – and we know that those living in energy poverty are mainly single-parent families, are families with many children or are elderly who are normally isolated. And in this sense, even if Member States have to have specific measures to combat energy poverty, they translate either into social tariffs or into the definition of critical periods where people are exempt from payment. My question is very simple: how can the European Union define what is a critical period for those living in poverty or on the poverty line? We are talking about 100 million, more than 100 million people in the European Union living in poverty, one in six people. Why does the European Union not clearly define what the measures are to prevent energy poverty? We are entering winter, which is a critical period, but for those who are poor all year round is a critical period, not just winter.

name: Traian Băsescu (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the report presents the overall situation, without analysing the differences in resources available to the Member States. If we look at the limitations imposed by the Climate Act, which is newly voted on in Parliament, and the Taxonomy Regulation, we find that, over time, we must eliminate energy produced from coal, hydrocarbons – including natural gas – and nuclear energy. This means, for example, for a country like Romania, that in the coming decades it will eliminate 60% of energy sources for the population and for industry, which makes it from an energy-independent country into a country that will have to resort to massive imports of electricity. Also, if we look at the Fund for a fair transition, we see that there is a big discrepancy between the objectives we have set ourselves and the resources we are making available to make the transition possible and to affect, let us say, equally, all the states of the European Union. That is why I believe that two conclusions are required: one, and the most important, is that we need to set realistic objectives and the second conclusion, the objectives that we set ourselves to be in full agreement with the financial resource we are allocating.

name: Miapetra Kumpula-Natri (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the climate neutrality target for 2050 requires systemic change and involves citizens. The EU has taken steps in the right direction and decoupled economic growth from greenhouse gas emissions. In 30 years, the EU cut emissions by 25%, while the economy grew by 62%. National energy and climate plans show that most Member States have cut emissions according to the current reduction targets, but Europe lags behind in the energy efficiency target. The renovation rates proposal could be one solution. We have to make it win-win-win: cut emissions, create local jobs, and make healthier homes and buildings. Renovation rates remain too low and renovations should be placed at the core of a sustainable recovery. Another big question for the energy transition is how to get private investment to support the green transition. Climate neutrality by 2050 needs investments now. The policy measures need to support predictability and also support demand for clean energy, green products and investments.

name: Bart Groothuis (Renew).
text: – Mr President, in the biggest energy transition in our history the biggest problem is not the technology to make it happen nor is it the political will to cut greenhouse gases. No, our biggest problem is that the perfect is becoming the enemy of the good. And just look at the political debates: no nuclear energy please, no carbon capture that entails fossil fuels, no biomass, no gas in a transition, no windmills in my backyard and no solar panels on agricultural grounds please. Well, altogether that is not a sustainable posture. How can we possibly be serious in reaching our climate goals without technologies like carbon capture, biomass or nuclear? But luckily there’s one technology we all agree on that has the potential to decarbonise at least our heavy industries and transport: hydrogen. It might not be a silver bullet but we all agree this energy carrier has enormous potential and our aim is clear: to create a new, clean produced, green hydrogen market and a long—term certainty for all parties involved, and that requires massive investments; in infrastructure, in the scale up of electrolysers, but also in carbon capture utilisation and storage, because we need to be realistic. If we want to pave the way for clean hydrogen we will initially need to invest in transitional technologies and these might not be perfect but they are good. So, yes, in the beginning of this huge transition we will still need fossil fuels and, therefore, EU policies should support carbon capture, enable government support schemes for blue hydrogen, and I expect the Commission to move forward in this direction in its energy summer package. We have 30 years to reshape our entire energy system and we can do it, and we will fail if we demand to be perfect, but we will definitely succeed by doing it as good as we can.

name: Jordan Bardella (ID).
text: Mr President, the European Commission has made the energy transition a major focus of its policy, including the goal of carbon neutrality in 2050. If the real goal is to decarbonize energy then where is nuclear in your reports? Nowhere is it recognized as an essential technology to promote, even though it is known to be the cheapest and most decarbonized energy source available to us today, making France the second cleanest country in the world in terms of energy, according to a report by Yale University. You swear by the last IPCC report, but you refuse to read it in its entire entire way. All scenarios, I mean all scenarios, which should limit the rise in temperature by 2100 include a massive increase in nuclear power. While hydrogen is probably the most reasonable ambition, wind, destructive of our landscapes, as electric batteries have demonstrated their limits. It is therefore time for the European Commission to return to reason and to science, to stop submitting to the pressures of the green ayatollahs and their anti-nuclear hysteria, so is our industrial and energy independence.

name: Jordi Solé (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, just some days ago, a study was released signalling that in Barcelona, the city from where I’m speaking today, air pollution still causes a thousand deaths a year, and this is largely due to the use of fossil fuels. However, despite the broad consensus on the need to accelerate the clean energy transition and step up our efforts concerning emissions reduction, fossil fuel subsidies actually continue to increase. This is one of the findings of the State of the Energy Union report. It is very urgent that we put forward a strategy towards subsidies that is coherent with the Green Deal. The EU should stop subsidising fossil fuels – and should urge Member States to do the same – and should instead redirect public money to finance the green energy transition. This is all the more urgent given that, as the report points out and the Commissioner said, funding of green energy research and investment is slowing. This comes on top of the huge cuts that the Council is proposing to the research programme Horizon Europe, which, of course, we are opposing head-on.

name: Izabela-Helena Kloc (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by A month ago, France had to restart its coal-fired power plants because the old Fessenheim nuclear power plant was closed and wind farms were unable to produce enough energy. The Germans also reached out to the traditional energy industry and set up a coal-fired power plant in Datteln. As you can see, stability and energy security cannot be achieved without fossil fuels. This also applies to natural gas, which should be recognised by the European Union as an important transitional raw material in the energy transition process. Unfortunately, green radicalism in EU legislation deprives Member States of their energy independence.  I therefore call on you to have more political realism. By imposing unattainable standards forcing absurd costs that exacerbate energy poverty, we are unfortunately leading to a very poor situation for people in Europe. All this is compounded by the cost of a pandemic. You have to remember. Look at this from a human perspective, not just from the perspective of business and eco-ideology.

name: András Gyürk (PPE).
text: Thank you for the floor, Mr President. The European Energy Union was established five years ago, so it is timely to discuss the initiative on three aspects: the results, lessons learned and the prospects achieved. In the light of the results, it can be stated that the Energy Union is a success story. The majority of Member States have been able to reduce their emissions with a growing economy, increasing the share of renewable energy sources in the energy mix. Due to the successful network development objectives and the development of an integrated energy market, the European energy network is much better prepared today to deal with the various shocks than before. Among the lessons learned, the conditions for success should be highlighted. Such results can indeed be achieved with well-founded objectives, respect and a Consensus Commission. For the latter, I would like to thank Commissioner Cañete. The prospects for the Energy Union, on the other hand, are far from encouraging.  The left has turned energy policy into a debate of faith. A left-wing majority in the European Parliament, by voting for a climate regulation on an ideological basis, would steer the Union towards a future that could lead to economic stagnation, hundreds of thousands of job losses and an explosion in overhead costs. It's risky. The people of Europe deserve a better climate and energy policy.

name: Łukasz Kohut (S&D).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by We have already defeated many nationalisms in the European Union – not all, but many. One of those that we are still dealing with is energy nationalism. The vast majority of Member States look at the issue of energy security through the lens of their borders, their economic and financial interests. Yet the Union is a community of values, it is the free movement of people, goods, services and capital. It is a shared responsibility for EU citizens, for their energy security. It is a shared commitment to combating energy poverty.  The Energy Union report shows perfectly how much we need solidarity in this area. We already have elements of it, such as the Just Transition Fund, but we need more. We need a real internal energy market. We do not need projects that undermine energy solidarity, such as Nord Stream 2.  And another word about decarbonization. Here we need to define precisely what we want to achieve. And I'm not talking about percentages, reductions or statistics. I am talking about specific people who, losing their jobs in mining, as in Silesia, have to get them in another industry. Let us remember, man is the most important. It is man who must stand in the middle of the energy transition.

name: Nicola Danti (Renew).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the report on the state of the Energy Union in 2020 rightly emphasises the impact of the pandemic in this sector and proposes a recovery phase that is in line with the objectives of the digital and green transition.  In this sense, I am convinced that it is precisely the instrument of recovery and resilience that will give a new impetus to the Member States, which will have to allocate at least 37 % of the resources of each plan to the climate transition. Covid has also highlighted even more highlighted the need for the European Union to reduce vulnerability and foreign dependence in this field too, improving the resilience and diversification of supply chains, as well as storage capacity. All Member States will have to continue to contribute to ensuring that the 2030 targets first, and the climate neutrality target in 2050, are then achievable in practice, consistent with the commitments made under the Paris Agreement. This does not mean imposing a strategy of industrial degrowth, but starting a process of energy transformation decisively in all sectors, such as radically rethinking our habits as well. I am thinking of Smart mobility, alternative fuels, the conversion of energy-intensive industries and the digitisation of energy infrastructure; last but not least, I am thinking of the role played by hydrogen, which, in an integrated energy system, has the possibility of promoting the decarbonisation of the transport, electricity and construction industries throughout Europe.  However, Commissioner, we need the appropriate resources, and the development of increasingly sustainable energy and economic systems will depend on investment in research and innovation, investments that can further increase the competitiveness of renewable energies, especially in terms of energy needs and costs.

name: Vincenzo Sofo (ID).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Caucasus, Africa, the Middle East, Eastern Europe, all areas on which we depend energetically, all areas where foreign powers are fuelling instability and conflict in order to put us in check. That is why Europe, if it wants to be a geopolitical player, strong and autonomous, needs energy sovereignty, sovereignty that must therefore represent the heart of the environmental challenge of the Green Deal, not the pursuit of the whims of Greta and multinationals that want to behead our companies, with taxes on meat, plastics and various follies. Not submission to China as it would be by focusing only on electricity.  The objective must be to guarantee Europe's autonomy, exploiting the energy potential of all its Member States and Italy has all the cards to be the protagonist, solar, wind, hydrogen, not to mention wave energy with realities such as NOEL in Calabria, thanks to which the first zero-impact marina could be born in Locride.  So if you want to build a europe that is a power, you value this reality and we will be the first to support you. If, on the other hand, you are prepared to kill our economies, in order to be greta's doormats, then we will be the first to fight them.

name: Jutta Paulus (Verts/ALE).
text: – (beginning of the speech when the micro is switched off) ... we are here today. I would like to focus on the role of renewable energies: we have three good news that are also included in your report. Firstly, renewables now supply more than 20% of final energy in the European Union. Electricity generation from solar and wind more than doubled between 2010 and 2018. And, perhaps most importantly for some in this House, renewables are superior to fossil-nuclear energy sources in terms of value creation and job creation.  However, the Member States' expansion targets are absolutely not sufficient to sufficiently reduce our emissions by 2030, and that is why we need a huge joint effort. And many citizens know this and are ready to do so. That is why I call on you, Mrs Simson, here today: please ensure that the rights for citizens' energy enshrined in the Clean Energy Package are implemented quickly and effectively in all Member States. Then we will have a real energy union, unleash renewables, democratise energy supply, secure local added value and achieve our climate targets.

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner Simson, the report on the state of the Energy Union brings the great problem of energy poverty back to the fore. Although progress has been made in the European Union as a whole, in my own country, Greece, the situation has deteriorated dramatically in recent years. In particular, in 2018, 22.7% of the population reported that they were unable to keep their home warm enough during the winter months, while the corresponding average in the European Union is only 7.3%. Similarly, in 2018, 35.6% of the population did not meet their financial obligations for energy bills due to financial difficulties, while the European Union average is only 6.6%.  National energy and climate plans, Commissioner, are the key to tackling the major issue of energy poverty. At the same time, however, large-scale programmes are needed to upgrade buildings and homes in the affected areas, with an emphasis on the use of cyclical materials, renewable energy sources and innovative technological solutions. We need to mobilise all available financial instruments from the Recovery Fund, the Community budget, the European Investment Bank and the private sector. Only with such action will we tackle the problem, create jobs and leave energy poverty behind.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D).
text: – Mr President, today we are debating the state of energy in very different circumstances from those in which we have done so in previous years, and in these circumstances we have to put all policies and tools at the service of recovery and resilience. The good governance of the Energy Union must take into account this new ambition of green leadership. Having been part of the energy governance regulation negotiating team, I am pleased to note the European Commission's positive assessment of the content of national energy and climate plans. The targets set for 2030 remain within our reach. Interconnection goals are delayed, need a political forcing. I call on us, without losing sight of the targets, to focus on the process and its impact, on ensuring clean energy at lower prices for businesses and households, on substantially reducing energy poverty, on investing in new models of distribution and storage and on new technologies such as green hydrogen, which allow all sectors of the Ecological Pact to be involved and the single energy market strengthened.

name: Jakop G. Dalunde (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I would also like to thank the Commission for an important report, which shows the role of energy policy in our efforts to reduce climate change. And this year's Energy State of the Union shows that we are still spending more money across the EU on fossil subsidies than we do on expanding renewable energy – even twice as much. That is EUR 50 billion annually that we spend on pumping artificial respiration into yesterday's technology. Climate policy must never be something that stops at rhetoric or pompous speech. I would therefore like to remind you that, only a few weeks ago, we in the European Parliament voted on the European Climate Act, including new targets for 2030. And these new objectives must represent a paradigm shift in our legislative process. The climate crisis is acute and the future is 100% renewable. And that is what we have to work for.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the European Green Deal and green recovery are of rather strategic importance for the Union, not only to reach our climate ambitions and respond to climate change, but also in terms of ensuring a fair, yet competitive, energy transition. Since last year, the Commission has presented initiatives to step up climate ambitions, not only to reach the target for 2030, but also for the long term. I think that we need to update existing legislation, but we also need new proposals as well, for example, in the field of renewables. For Member States to achieve the decarbonisation target, we need first an achievable target for all Member States, taking into consideration also the different starting points of each. We need an agreement that would be beneficial for everyone.  Secondly, I may say that we, the policymakers, need to ensure that transition is possible for all regions, including those dependent on coal, and that no sector of industry should be further affected, especially given the COVID-19 economic pandemic impact. We need to back the green transition with a consistent and horizontal energy policy, and a modern, climate-neutral, highly resource efficient and competitive industrial base in the EU. As a conclusion, along this way, in the process, we need to ensure consistency across policies, streamlined Green Deal ambitions, with a feasible transition leaving no region behind, ensuring the resilience of our energy system and the security of our energy supply.

name: Robert Hajšel (S&D).
text: – Mr President, renewable energy and energy efficiency are the cornerstones of the energy transition. Renewable energy will provide the majority of clean electricity in the decades to come. However, huge capital will also be needed to transform Europe’s energy infrastructure. Strategic choices about where to invest must be made now, taking into account the need to phase out fossil fuel subsidies.  But take gas as a fossil fuel: it can be a helpful bridging transitionary medium to be used in many Member States if we want to achieve our ambitious climate targets. The gas infrastructure can be used also for the clean hydrogen technology if slightly modified. We need to stop talking only about the energy targets, we have to speak about how to implement these. Today our role is to facilitate a just transition, and also recovery, by linking those opportunities with the needs of people who don’t want to fall into energy poverty, where there are already about 50 million Europeans.

name: Manuela Ripa (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Almost every day we invoke the European Green Deal, almost every day we describe meticulously how precisely we are now tackling climate protection – and then comes this figure, for which we must be grateful to the Commission. The Member States spend 50 billion euros a year on fossil fuel subsidies. This is the third highest amount of subsidies we spend in the EU. This bafflyses you and shows that governments are acting in completely contradictory form. On the one hand, we want to increase CO2 prices with the ETS, we all know that they are far too low. On the other hand, the Member States are spending this incredibly large sum on the reduction of CO2. We must also see the bigger picture in energy policy.  Therefore, let's immediately ban energy subsidies for fossilfuels! Let us put this subsidy directly and immediately into renewables! The Commission is invited to come to Parliament with such a proposal. You would get applause for that.

name: Kadri Simson
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the State of the Energy Union is an opportunity for all of us to take a close look at our energy policy, to assess the progress we have made and identify the areas where we need to do even better. It is an extremely thorough exercise to make sure that all the dimensions of our energy policy are delivering and this year’s report is not only the first one since the Green Deal, it is also the first one since the delivery and assessment of the final national energy and climate plans. There will be many opportunities to engage with Member States, stakeholders, and of course with the European Parliament, in the coming months on our clean energy transformation and its challenges, and I trust that this report is a good basis to kick off such a dialogue. As already mentioned during my introduction, the State of the Energy Union contains important additional reports, notably, let me highlight again, the first competitiveness report that is part of the State of the Energy Union. It shows that green energy is outperforming the conventional energy technologies; also the price of renewables has come down significantly, and the energy efficiency first principle in the renovation wave helps us to create jobs across all the EU. So lower heating bills for households, and it also helps us save energy, and energy poverty across EU has declined but this is still 34 million people too many who struggle to afford a comfortable temperature in their homes. So the Green Deal and the clean energy transition is an opportunity also for the economy to relaunch investment and jobs. Our programme for the next year is to strongly build on these conclusions and we have just adopted the renovation wave, the hydrogen strategy, and we will very soon present our offshore renewable strategy. But we also made a commitment to look at and assess all our basic instruments when it comes to the energy efficiency and renewables. All of these actions are now part of our work programme for 2021.  And this is what the Green Deal means – a cleaner, more competitive, fairer Europe. The EU’s current framework will not allow us to reach our 2050 goals and meet our commitments under the Paris Agreement. Simply continuing to implement the clean energy package would see the EU achieving a 60% reduction of greenhouse gas emissions by 2050. This is not enough to get to the Paris Agreement. The EU needs to raise its ambition for this decade now and the impact assessment we have conducted shows that a balanced realistic pathway to carbon neutrality by 2050 requires an emissions reduction target of 55% by 2030. This is why the Commission proposes to cut emissions faster by 2030.  Now let me briefly also touch upon the importance of nuclear safety because I received yesterday a letter from 40 Members of Parliament expressing their concerns regarding the safety of the Astravets nuclear power plant in Belarus. I would like to reiterate the Commission’s commitment to ensuring the highest levels of nuclear safety globally, and especially in the EU’s closest neighbourhood. In the case of Astravets power plant this means verifying that all key safety recommendations from the European Nuclear Safety Regulators Group (ENSREG) are implemented prior to the start of commercial operations of the power plant in early 2021.  The 7 November event is a one-off operation to test the generation of a small quantity of electricity. The peer review by ENSREG’s nuclear safety experts is well underway. It is important that the experts are able to complete their work, which would allow them to draw their own independent conclusions. The peer review is expected to be completed prior to the commercial operation of the plant.  The Commission is making great efforts to maintain engagements with Belarus in this regard. However, we will need to operate within the current political reality of the political developments in Belarus. Nonetheless, the Commission is prepared to apply increased political pressure to see that the key recommendations are not implemented before the start of the commercial operation of the plant. This is also about our energy union.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. I welcomed the report by the European Commission. Integrating EU energy policy is in the fundamental interest of our citizens, as the creation of an Energy Union is a prerequisite for delivering on our climate commitments by 2050. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. In addition to climate protection, another important objective of the Energy Union is to reduce the vulnerability of EU Member States to energy sources. The promotion and deployment of renewable energy sources therefore not only serves climate protection purposes, but also helps EU Member States to ensure the security of energy supply for their citizens themselves. While EU directives promote strategic self-sufficiency at EU level, the governments of some Member States, such as the Orban government, are increasingly dependent on Russia for energy supply. If you are not buying gas from them, you will buy a nuclear power plant that will never be able to generate electricity at market prices. We are fighting to make the Union a liveable place today, tomorrow and 50 years from now, so it is urgent to set up the Energy Union as soon as possible.

name: Susana Solís Pérez (Renew)
text: in writing. – The State of the Energy Union is a key instrument for measuring our progression towards cleaner energy that allows us to meet the decarbonisation commitments approved in the Climate Act by 2030 and 2050. The State of the Energy Union allows us to analyse the weaknesses of our energy system and, above all, to show ourselves which points we should invest the most in. New recovery and cohesion funds should be a key weapon in ensuring better energy efficiency of buildings, investing in sustainable mobility plans and reducing the use of fossil fuels for individuals and industry through progressive electrification and investment in alternative sources such as green hydrogen and renewable energy. It is time to engage civil society, foster innovation and private public collaboration in order to achieve greater energy independence and a greener and more digital Europe. Recovery funds, together with programs such as CEF or the Fair Transition Fund, offer a unique opportunity to address the challenges of the future without leaving anyone behind.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission's statement on the adaptation of the Energy Charter Treaty to the European Green Deal (2020/2827(RSP)). I would like to inform you that, as we know, all debates cannot accept spontaneous speeches, blue cards or points of order. In this debate, too, we will be turning on colleagues who speak online from the liaison offices. You also know that, in the course of this debate, President Sassoli will come to tell us, after the meeting of the Conference of Presidents, the winner of the Sakharov Prize.

name: Kadri Simson
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members of the European Parliament, I would like to thank you for this opportunity to debate on this important topic today. The Energy Charter Treaty is in need of substantial reform. In the past years, the European Union, including this Parliament and the Member States, have repeatedly called for a modernisation of the charter. The need for reform is also considered necessary by most of the other contracting parties.  Based on its negotiating mandate, the Commission has engaged in this negotiation with determination and a clear position. However, we know that a successful modernisation of the Energy Charter Treaty will be a challenge, and it will require that all the contracting parties and stakeholders contribute to this collective result. For the EU, the objective of making the Energy Charter Treaty green is at the heart of the modernisation process. Member States have given their permission, a mandate to negotiate, which reflects the EU’s reformed investment project protection standards, and ensures strong sustainable development provisions. The Commission also has a duty to make the Energy Charter future—proof, so that it can help us address climate change, and clean energy transition goals, and facilitate a transition to a low carbon energy system in line with the objectives of the Paris Agreement. With the adoption of the European Green Deal and the EU commitment to move to climate neutrality by 2050, the European Commission has now stepped up its climate ambitions.  Once confirmed by the co-legislators, the revised greenhouse gas emissions reduction targets for 2030 will need to be reflected in our negotiations. A level of ambition, as proposed by the Commission for at least 55% greenhouse gas reduction, requires transposition into concrete actions, including in the external dimension of the UN energy and climate policies. Honourable Members, let me update you on the progress of the Energy Charter Treaty’s modernisation process.  The negotiations with the energy charter’s contracting parties have started in 2020. We had two rounds of negotiations so far, in July and September. A third round is scheduled for 3 until 6 November, another round is already planned for the end of February, or March 2021.  Based on the negotiating directives adopted by the Council in July 2019, the Commission submitted in advance of the first round of negotiations, a proposal addressing specifically investment protection and dispute settlement.  The text proposed also puts forward new provisions on sustainable development in the area of climate change, and clean energy transition in particular. These provisions recognise the urgent need of pursuing the Paris Agreement in order to effectively combat climate change and its impacts, and to regulate to that effect, at national level. Our ambition in the modernisation reflects the EU’s leading role in ensuring that the energy transition happens also in partner countries, in line with the Paris Agreement goals. For this reason, we will proceed with a pragmatic and realistic approach to ensure successful outcomes.  The complex negotiations ahead of us involve a variety of factors, and require increased cooperation, and accelerated efforts, in order to achieve the necessary consensus among all contracting parties, some of which are at different stages of development of their energy and climate policies. We can trust that the European Green Deal is at the core of our EU policy. It is our political aim, to ensure that the Energy Charter Treaty only protects those investments that support transition to a climate neutral energy system.  I want to make the European Charter a tool also for a clean energy transition that is aligned with our EU agenda and with our collective goals under the Paris Agreement. We count on the European Parliament to support us in this process.

name: Maria Spyraki
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, the Energy Charter Treaty provides a multilateral framework for energy cooperation that is unique under international law. Today 81% of investments protected by the Energy Charter Treaty are intra—EU investments. However, it is important to recognise that the Treaty is outdated, notably when it comes to arbitration clauses between foreign investors and Member States. The Treaty must reinstate Europe’s rights to regulate, particularly on the issue of climate change. We must insist on the establishment of a multilateral investment court.  Our response to the voices asking to withdraw collectively from the Energy Charter Treaty, in order to allow for the implementation of Europe’s clean energy package, must be a deep revision of the Treaty, addressing the Paris Agreement deals and aligning with our Green Deal road map, in order to reshape our economy into green and digital, and finally secure that this alignment will provide sustainable and affordable energy prices for all consumers. But we are not naive. Unanimity requires compromise. We must work multilaterally in finally concluding a forward-looking Energy Charter Treaty, with the clear provision of phasing out fossil fuels, with the safeguarding of energy security through the operation of more open and competitive energy markets, while respecting the principles of sustainable development and sovereignty over energy resources.

name: Kathleen Van Brempt
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, let me be quite clear, crystal clear, the Energy Charter Treaty is not in line with the Green Deal. It’s an instrument of the past, it’s even an instrument of a former decade. Favouring large fossil fuel companies over the environment is not the way forward. It’s not adapted to the current reality, and not to our climate ambitions. As has been stated also in the former debate, there’s a fundamental reform necessary in our energy system and we will not succeed doing that if the ECT continues to protect fossil fuel investments. Moreover, and that is very interesting and very frightening to see, that it is expected that more cases targeting climate policies will arise, once Member States start to implement the commitments that they have made in line with the Green Deal and the Paris Agreement, and that is unacceptable.  So we need a fundamental reform of the ECT. This will not be easy, as for instance, Japan already stated that it is not in favour of a fundamental reform. I want to be also crystal clear on what the next step should be, that if it is not possible to have a fundamental reform, I think it’s absolutely necessary that the EU prepares itself to withdraw from the ECT. We’ve made that clear also in a former debate, and in a former a vote on the climate law, where we clearly made a statement on the ECT.  So my question to the Commission is very simple. The Commissioner thinks it is possible to align the ECT with the Green Deal. I do not doubt the good intentions that the Commissioner has, and the Commission overall, but I do doubt that we have the good partners in place to make that reform possible: will you be able and ready to withdraw from the treaty the moment that you see there is no possibility for a good reform?

name: Martin Hojsík
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, it’s great that we are having this debate, but this should be only the start. We need to put the spotlight on the Energy Charter Treaty and ensure that it receives the attention that it needs. And it deserves attention, because as they say ‘Houston, we have a problem’. Problem, that the Treaty that we only experts only really know about can cost us billions in compensation for private companies, often shell companies. If we want to prevent catastrophic climate change costs us public money that we urgently need to avert the climate crisis. Because the Energy Charter Treaty as it stands is not and, I repeat, not compatible with the European Green Deal nor several international legally binding commitments, let’s say, for example, the Paris Agreement. We have a problem if we, for example, invest now in gas and in twenty years, we need to shut it down because we have available alternative and ran out of the carbon budget. What do we do then? Start compensating all the investors? To put it simple, we cannot and should not protect investments into fossil fuels. The risk of climate crisis is already known to all investors; they don’t need the protection and they should not get it. Now this is where you might expect me to tell you the solution, but I will not. Right now, I want the Commission and the Member States to tell us, the citizens of Europe, what you want to do about it. You want to renegotiate – that’s good to hear, but what do you do if the negotiations fail? Because when it comes to climate, we cannot afford to fail. We would not be forgiven.

name: Markus Buchheit (ID).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. Welcome back. It already seems that the Fridays for Future demos have slowly disappeared from the front pages of the tabloids, but zombie-like their demands reverberate here in the everyday business of the Union. What madness must we, as policymakers, be in a position to further fuel the exogenous shock of the global pandemic caused by the Green Deal, which is not yet manageable in its scale? We are talking about an alignment with the Green Deal – wonderful words! They are selling the much-vaunted green turn to the citizens here as the European Men on the Moon project, as an absolute necessity – now immediately – with CO2 reductions of 55 or 60%, no matter what impact assessments, what impact these figures will actually have on our industry and society.  Already today, the price of electricity for our industry in Germany is almost three times higher than in the USA, and it will continue to rise. This will cost us competitiveness, and in the end, of course, prosperity. You know that in the Commission, and that is why the next absurd idea complements an absurd idea. This is the Green Deal, for example, through the carbon border adjustment mechanism or, as we have heard today, by the withdrawal from the ECT.  If, for years, we have condemned other states here in the EU for protectionism and isolationism, we are now doing it ourselves. Commissioner, you spoke earlier about believing in the Green Deal. Faith is beautiful, but what are the numbers? What will these measures actually cost us in the end?

name: Anna Cavazzini
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, whenever I speak to citizens about the Energy Charter Treaty they are shocked. The Energy Charter Treaty allows investors to bring EU Member States in front of private arbitration panels because those governments want to fulfil the requirements of the Paris Agreement. The Energy Charter Treaty makes governments pay billions of taxpayers’ money just because they want to fight the climate crisis and implement the Green Deal. And does this sound completely insane? Yes, it does, but it is the truth and the Energy Charter Treaty is the embodiment of a fossil era that has to come to an end. And this is why the reform by the Commission is so overdue and also welcomed. But I have two major concerns to bring before the Commissioner. First, we need an effective reform. So the Commission must delete fossil fuels from the definition of economic activities and thus end the protection of fossil fuels. And second, we have to face the reality. An effective reform is very unlikely, given the anonymity required. So I urge the Commission to set a clear deadline and prepare for leaving the Treaty. And I know, Madam Commissioner, you will come now with a sunset clause. Yes, the sunset clause is bad; it protects investment for another 20 years if we leave the Energy Charter Treaty now. But better leaving earlier than later. At the very least, we need to end inner EU application and thus eliminate already half of the cases. I count on your support.

name: Beata Szydło
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Honourable Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. The realities of energy and climate policy are changing very quickly. There is a growing need to strengthen regional and global cooperation in this area. We have only adopted the Paris Agreement in the last five years and the Green Deal strategy has been announced, so it is natural that we must also proceed with the amendment of the Energy Charter Treaty.  However, we should do so realistically, especially at this difficult time, when there is a pandemic crisis, when every job counts, when the economy needs to be supported. The demands for the modernisation of the Treaty should therefore be realistic. We must protect investment and make changes in line with the strategies we have developed before and, above all, with a view to supporting the economy.

name: Silvia Modig
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, at a time when the ECT Agreement is now being modernised, it is essential that it be brought to support the transition towards carbon-neutral societies. At the moment, it is not doing it, but vice versa, it is allowing companies to bring legal action against countries that want to change their legislation and therefore their energy palette towards a sustainable carbon-neutral model. The investment protection of the agreement protects fossil fuels, despite the fact that we know that they will significantly exacerbate the climate crisis. In addition, the investment protection clause contains a huge problem for democracy. Legislative changes are made by governments that have come to power in elections at the will of the people. When companies are given the opportunity to challenge these democratic decisions in the name of investment protection, they are given the right to question the opinion of the people in elections. Even now, companies can hold governments hostage by threatening arbitration if that country wanted, for example, to ban the use of coal. It will enable climate action to be prevented, watered down or abandoned for fear that it will lead to a multibillion-euro lawsuit. When we adopted the Climate Act, we adopted the record that all our policies must be in line with the objectives of the Climate Act, namely the Paris Agreement, as written in the Climate Act. The ECT Agreement is in complete conflict with the objectives of the Green Deal. It does not contain any objectives for reducing emissions or solving the climate crisis, and this must change in a fundamental way.  Commissioner, are you prepared to abandon and withdraw from the Treaty if there is no consensus on fundamental changes within a sufficient timeframe?

name: Sunčana Glavak (PPE).
text: - Dear Chairman, outdated provisions of the Energy Charter Treaty need to be modernised in line with the European Commission's latest objectives of limiting the impact of climate change. In order to actually contribute to the achievement of the climate objectives set out in the Paris Agreement on the SDGs and the ambitions of the European Union, the ECT should encourage investment in low-carbon sustainable energy and, equally, support measures to promote a just transition. However, in light of the urgent need for climate action, what ect really needs is a thorough recast. Today's debate, I believe, may have a positive impact not only on thinking about the necessary changes to achieve climate goals, but also on other ECT provisions that also have a significant negative impact on the international legal order. We need to stop fossil fuel investments and remove unfavorable provisions that actually give investors the ability to file lawsuits against states before private arbitral tribunals. We've heard something about that today.  The biggest challenge perhaps facing Member States is the investor protection clause. In fact, it allows them to be entitled to compensation if they are unable to realise the investment in the event of a change in policy and regulation. This clause is often abused. A total of 134 lawsuits by energy companies against states have been filed against states, according to ect secretariat data, with almost half of the proceedings still ongoing. I will conclude, the European Union is based on the rule of law and respect for positive legal regulations. The interests of our citizens must be a priority.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: I cannot continue with the debate at the moment because I am now suspending the announcement by the President of the Winner of the Sakharov Prize. We are immediately resonating with the debate after this communication.

name: Presidente. –
text: Ladies and gentlemen, it is a great honour for me to inform you that the Conference of Presidents has decided to award the Sakharov Prize for Freedom of Thought to the representatives of the Belarusian opposition: the Coordinating Council, the courageous women's initiative Sviatlana Tsikhanouskaya, Svetlana Alexievich, Maryia Kalesnikava, Volha Kavalkova, Veranika Tsapkala, and political and civil society personalities Siarhei Tsikhanouski, Ales Bialiatski , Siarhei Dyleuski, Stsiapan Putsila and Mikola Statkevich.  The massive street protests in Belarus that have moved the whole world have been going on for 11 weeks now. As our admiration for the people of Belarus grows, so is our dismay at Lukashenko's violent reprisals and his acts of torture and denial of the truth. Allow me to reiterate what our institutions and Parliament have already said with one voice: the government and the President have lost the elections and the time has come to listen to the voice of its people.  More importantly, however, I would like to congratulate the representatives of the Belarusian opposition on their courage, resilience and determination. They embody on a daily basis the defence of freedom of thought and expression that the Sakharov Prize rewards. They have proven themselves and continue to be strong in the face of a much more powerful opponent. But what sustains them is something that violence can never defeat: the truth. So here is mine, our message for you, dear winners of the prize: continue to be strong and do not give up your battles, we will be at your side. Know that we are with you. I hope to be able to welcome you to Parliament soon to give you the prize that we have awarded you today.  I would also like to say a word about the recent murder of one of this year's finalists, Mr Arnold Joaquín Morazán Erazo, leader of the Environmental Group in Guapinol, the group that is opposing an iron oxide mine in Honduras. A very important significant battle. It is imperative that a credible and independent investigation is launched immediately and that those responsible are held to account.  In Honduras, Belarus, Iraq and anywhere else in the world, no one should be persecuted for expressing their opinions. That is the message we want to send out today from the European Parliament.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: We are now continuing our debate on the Commission's statement on the adaptation of the Energy Charter Treaty to the European Green Deal (2020/2827(RSP)) following President Sassoli's statement on the Sakharov Prize winners.

name: Aurore Lalucq (S&D).
text: Mr President, dear Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the European Commission has made the ecological issue its flagship project through the Green Pact for Europe. This Parliament declared a climate emergency last year. We voted a few weeks ago on the climate bill. However, all this is useless if the energy charter continues because you know as well as I do that every time a state wants to put in place ambitious environmental legislation, it will be attacked or threatened with being attacked in private arbitration courts, with the consequences that we know, either the law is swept, it is lightened or the states have to pay millions or even billions of euros. , public money, citizens' money, money we need to implement the ecological transition. Money we need more than we need in a time of crisis. This archaic and climate-efficient treaty works as a real life insurance for fossil industries, life insurance against our lives. Since negotiations are currently underway, we parliamentarians would like to know what are the Commission's red lines? And if this treaty is not renegotiable, which is really our fear, we would like to know whether the Commission is determined to organise a concerted exit from this treaty, so that we can put in place the ecological transition.

name: Marie-Pierre Vedrenne (Renew).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, this is a fact that we all share: our trade and investment policies must contribute to compliance with the Paris Agreement and to the implementation of our commitments set out in the Green Pact. One consequence: the current energy charter treaty is inadequate with our objectives to combat climate change. So two priorities in the negotiations that you have already mentioned. First, to be hired to exclude fossil fuels from the scope of the treaty. How many companies operating in this sector have attacked our states and won! And these cases are likely to multiply with our goal of climate neutrality. Second, to be committed to the abandonment of the old investor-state dispute settlement mechanism in this treaty. The right to recoil from states must be protected. But a reality: unfortunately, few if any of the current signatories to this treaty share this desire to adapt. So only one conclusion, Commissioner, is urgent to prepare for all situations, including the organised withdrawal from these negotiations.

name: Saskia Bricmont (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, the European Commission has adopted an ambitious green pact for Europe. Just a fortnight ago, the European Parliament voted on the climate law, which plans to reduce our emissions by 60% by 2030. And yet we are stuck in texts that date back to the 1990s, which do not integrate the climate emergency.  We must stop procrastinating and leave the Energy Charter Treaty, which provides for the protection of investments in fossil fuels and the mechanism for settling disputes between investors and states, which also provides for a supremacy clause, thus a superiority of this text over any subsequent text, such as the Paris Agreement, and which also provides for the unanimity of decisions between 50 members. Just over 50 members who cannot agree on sustainability issues. This is particularly problematic with a country like Japan, with which we have concluded a trade agreement and negotiated chapters on sustainable development, which should allow us to have common positions on the international stage. So, Commissioner, after two rounds of negotiations which cannot be seen and in view of the hostilities towards the modernisation of this Treaty, what is the Union's plan B to get out of it and protect itself from the effects of the Treaty?

name: Manuel Bompard (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Energy Charter Treaty was signed in 1994. It protects investments in fossil fuels by allowing multinationals to sue states in arbitration tribunals. It is, for example, Vattenfall that is suing Germany for tightening its environmental regulations; Uniper is attacking the Netherlands for deciding to close its coal-fired power plants; It is the Canadian company Vermilion that threatens France with lawsuits if it commits to ending fossil fuel extraction by 2040. This treaty now protects 30 gigatonnes of cumulative emissions, which is the equivalent of the carbon budget that the European Union has left by 2050 to meet the trajectory of the Paris agreement. However, our Parliament has set the target for carbon neutrality by 2050. Will we, in turn, be dragged before a court? Enough is enough, the financial interests of multinationals must not take precedence over the sovereignty of the people. So ladies and gentlemen, it is time to tear up the Energy Charter Treaty.

name: Miapetra Kumpula-Natri (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the Energy Charter Treaty (ECT) has been rightly criticised. Modernisation to make it compatible with the Green Deal is a necessity. I hope, however, that the Treaty’s shortcomings do not blind us from seeing how much we need a modernised treaty to cover renewable energy investments. The Commission estimation shows that for reduction of emissions by the goals we have set, the EU needs annually EUR 350 billion more energy-related investments than were made in the past 10 years. It is clear also that most of this will come from private investors. If we get the true ambitious modernisation that is sought in the EU text proposal, the ECT would then, in effect, become the enforcement tool for the Paris Agreement that we currently lack.  We should recognise that in the multilateral investment treaty covering renewable energy investments, and that no other treaty exists than the ECT. With the modernised treaty we could offer private investors protection and the stable investment environment that is needed to increase investments in renewables. It will not be easy to find an ambitious modernised treaty – unanimity is required among 54 parties to the agreement – but we have to push this and we have to convince our partners that all need an Energy Charter Treaty that is in line with the Green Deal.

name: Kadri Simson
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, once again I would like to thank you for this opportunity to debate on this important topic today. It is a sensitive one and you can trust that the Commission is following it very closely. The Commission will also need to address the definition of economic activity in the energy sector. In line with our mandate, the Commission wants to send a strong signal. Our aim is to ensure that economic activities related to the use of fossil fuels are phased out from the scope of the Charter’s investment section. The transition to a climate neutral energy system requires that the use of fossil fuels should be greatly diminished and eventually phased out. This approach is at the core of the European Green Deal and it is the approach we are following in the modernisation process. We have made it clear and engaged in very good faith in the reform. A successful Energy Charter Treaty negotiation outcome requires consensus. A proposal to remove the investment protection of fossil fuels from the Energy Charter Treaty would certainly be met with fierce resistance from many of the non-EU-ECT contracting parties, many of which are big fossil fuel producers. At the same time the EU has a duty to act in accordance with its long-term energy transition and climate goals which would require that the EU-ECT should only cover investments needed to support transition to a climate neutral energy system.  A balance needs to be struck and we believe that our approach does that. The Energy Charter Treaty protects not only investments in fossil fuels but also investment in electricity, irrespective of the energy source generating that electricity, which means that it also protects investments in renewable energy sources. Therefore, the Commission believes that the ECT could still play a positive role in the future by supporting the investments necessary for the energy transition in particular outside of the EU if all contracting parties accept the necessary changes to the treaty.  So right now, no option is off the table. The EU should first engage in the negotiations and see if partners engage. We must be aware that withdrawal is difficult, indeed the ECT has a 20-year sunset clause, therefore if the EU were to get out now, it would face the application of the unreformed ECT for the next 20 years in relation to investments in existence at the time of withdrawal. So, first, we negotiate and we are ready to assess all options if negotiations do not deliver the result.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Łukasz Kohut (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – For more than two decades, the European Energy Charter has governed cooperation between more than fifty countries in the world, as well as the European Union, on energy issues. This is the treaty we need. But it is also a treaty that needs urgent renegotiation. The Member States and regions of the Union, which are currently making a heroic effort for a just transition, like my Silesia, must not be weakened by outdated, inadequate regulations. The European Union is withdrawing from coal and other fossil fuels. Meanwhile, the European Energy Charter, as it stands, could protect well over EUR 2 trillion in fossil fuel investments by 2050. Investments not of ours, but of third countries, which may additionally result in liability for compensation of Union countries. This is an unacceptable situation. An urgent renegotiation of the Charter is a necessity.
